pages.title: Board meeting – 31 May 2012 | NHS England
pages.content: We hold our board meetings in public in the interests of openness and transparency in our decision making. The next public board meeting will take place, at the Birmingham University Edgbaston campus, on Thursday 31 st May 2012 from 10.30am to 1.00pm in the: Nicolson Building (next to) Winterbourne House & Botanical Gardens 58 Edgbaston Park Road Birmingham B15 2RT This is location G12 on the downloadable map . The Nicolson building is about 10 minutes by cab from Birmingham New Street train station and free parking is provided onsite which will be clearly marked in front of the conference building. See also the website for the venue . Registration at the event starts from 10am. If you would like to attend, please register your interest as places are limited. Please contact commissioningboard@nhs.net or call Finn Dudaniec, by 12 noon on Wednesday 30th May, on 0113 254 6550. Please note that members of the public are welcome to attend meetings of the Board – which although being held in public are not public meetings. Questions submitted via this website won’t be passed on for discussion at Board meetings but will receive a response. The board meeting will be broadcast live as part of our commitment to make information as accessible as possible. The livestream is best viewed in Firefox , Google Chrome or Internet Explorer 8 and 9 with the latest version of Adobe Flash Player . You may experience issues viewing this content in Internet Explorer 6 and 7. View a recording of the board meeting on Ustream A separate recording of each agenda item is also available. You can view the agenda and board papers below. Board meeting agenda Item 1 – Minutes from previous meeting Decisions of the public Board meeting held 31 May 2012 Board papers Item 2 – NHS Commissioning Board programme update Item 3 – Update on end state running cost position of the NHS Commissioning Board 2013-14 and 2014-15 Item 4 – Design of the NHS operations directorate Item 5 – Emerging clinical commissioning group configuration: names, geography and constituent members Annex 1: List of emerging CCG names to be put forward for authorisation along with indicative running cost allowance Annex 2: Clinical commissioning groups in England proposed geographic boundaries Annex 3: CCGs confirmed for waves 1, 2, 3 and 4 for authorisation List of proposed known constituent member practices within each proposed CCG (data taken from April 2011) Comments on this page are now closed. Share: Tweet

pages.title: Bulletin for proposed CCGs – Issue 14, 24 May 2012 | NHS England
pages.content: Contents Welcome from Barbara Hakin Proposed CCG configuration and member practices published CCG indicative running cost allowances CCG authorisation waves agreed CCG authorisation: Wave 1 workshops CCG authorisation: Recruitment of assessors Assessment centres and development process underway Commissioning support services pass second stage of review Communications and engagement commissioning support services Commissioning support: Informed customer events for CCGs NHS Commissioning Board: New appointments and organisational design Any qualified provider Payment by results: a new guide Free places offered to CCGs at commissioning conferences Welcome from Barbara Hakin Welcome to the latest bulletin for proposed CCGs. In this issue we’ve got the welcome news that the proposed configuration and member practices for 212 proposed CCGs has been published for the first time. We’re also publishing the indicative running cost allowances and the proposed CCG applicants for the four authorisation waves. This information is contained in a paper for the NHS Commissioning Board Authority’s board meeting on 31 May 2012. Taken together, this is a real landmark in our work to establish the new clinical commissioning system and proposed CCGs are to be congratulated on the progress they are making. It means that we now have planning assumptions for every practice in the country, every practice is now part of a proposed CCG, and every proposed CCG has a settled geography and a date scheduled for its authorisation application. Most importantly, it means that everyone living in England will be covered by a CCG from April 2013. It is important to emphasise at this point that for patients registered with a GP practice, the responsible commissioner will be the CCG of which that practice is a member. For unregistered patients, the responsible commissioner will be the CCG in whose area they live. CCGs will also be responsible for providing for emergency and urgent care for those within their boundary at the time of need. I also want to emphasise strongly that all the authorisation waves are equal and there is no difference between a CCG in wave one or wave four in terms of competence as I know from my visits to proposed CCGs. Proposed CCGs in each wave will continue to develop throughout the year as they take on increasing responsibilities, and could have conditions set irrespective of the wave in which they are placed. There is no advantage in being part of any particular wave as all CCGs will take on their new commissioning duties, if authorised, on 1 April 2013, regardless of their wave. We will continue to support proposed CCGs in a number of different ways as they continue their journey towards April 2013, and more information about leadership development and authorisation workshops is included in this bulletin. I talk to proposed CCG leaders each week and I know one of the issues that is still being discussed by many of you is identifying the nurse and doctor on the governing body of a CCG. The individual should have no conflicts of interest and so should not be employed by any organisation from which the CCG secures any significant volume of provision. When interpreting what might be considered to be a ‘significant volume’ proposed CCGs will need to include circumstances where contracts have been agreed between a CCG and a provider routinely to provide services for patients, but would not include occasional arrangements which a CCG made with a provider as a result of an individual patient exercising free choice. You may have already heard that earlier this month we published the outcome of the second stage in the business review process for commissioning support services (CSSs), known as ‘Checkpoint 2’. As part of this process, 25 regional NHS commissioning support services and the nationwide NHS Communications and Engagement Service submitted outline business plans and 23 CSSs were given the go-ahead to proceed. This is good news for the vast majority of areas and, while there are still significant challenges ahead, provides a solid basis on which proposed CCGs can now proceed in terms of agreeing plans for commissioning support. As you know we will shortly be appointing the managing directors to these 23 services and this will be another substantial step forward. There is more detail in the bulletin story below, but I’m also keen to highlight the next steps for communications and engagement commissioning support services as the proposed nationwide single organisation is not considered to be the right model. Communications and engagement services are an essential part of commissioning support and will continue as an ‘at scale’ offer. However, it is clear that the proposal of a single, national organisation did not win support from proposed CCGs and we have taken this feedback on board. The new proposals are being developed with CCG involvement which will build on the good work that has been done by all communications staff over recent months. These will be available in June in line with the rest of the CSS development process. Finally, I held two webinars at the beginning of May for CCG leaders (if you missed them you can download them here ) and will be holding two more on 4 July. In addition to those I am now also blogging! I’ll be jotting down my thoughts on various topics over the next few months on the NHS CBA website , along with other Commissioning Board colleagues. There is still much to do in a short time and, as always, if you have any questions, comments or feedback about the commissioning development programme, or you would like to be added to the mailing list to receive this bulletin directly, please email me at pathfinderlearningnetwork@nhs.net . Dame Barbara Hakin National Director for Commissioning Development Proposed CCG configuration and member practices published The NHS Commissioning Board Authority has published the proposed configuration and member practices for 212 proposed CCGs for the first time. This is a major step forward in the work to establish the new clinical commissioning landscape by April 2013, and, along with the publication of the running cost allowances (see story below), will enable proposed CCGs to further develop their organisation ready for authorisation and establishment. The information is in a paper for the Board Authority which will be asked to agree the configuration as the basis of authorisation at its board meeting on 31 May 2012. National and regional CCG maps have been published on the Board Authority’s website at the same time. The paper confirms that there are now proposed CCGs covering the whole of England and includes the detailed geographic areas for each for the first time, plus the planning assumptions about the member practices in each proposed CCG. This means that everyone living in England will be covered by a CCG. These planning assumptions will allow work to progress. Once the NHS Commissioning Board is established as a statutory body, it will check that legal requirements have been met and approve the final details of geography and names of CCGs through the authorisation process. Each proposed CCG has determined its own configuration within the framework set out by the Board Authority, which ensures that: there is sign up from member practices there is appropriate geographical coverage that allows a proposed CCG to take on responsibility for commissioning for a population where a proposed CCG straddles upper tier or unitary local authority boundaries, it is for patient interest reasons each proposed CCG is a viable organisation in terms of the degree of sharing of roles and functions, or the use of commissioning support that it will need to consider A full list of proposed CCGs and the national and regional maps can be seen on the Board Authority’s website. CCG indicative running cost allowances The NHS Commissioning Board Authority has published the indicative running cost allowances for 212 proposed CCGs for 2013-14 in a paper for noting by the Board Authority’s board meeting on 31 May. The running cost allowance for CCGs has already been set at upto £25 per head of population per year. This limit ensures that spending on running costs will be kept to a reasonable level and NHS funding will be focused on providing high quality services for patients and the public. The Board Authority has decided that the fairest approach to calculating running cost allowances for CCGs is to base them on the GP registered lists for practices within the CCG, but moderated at local authority level to match the Office for National Statistics’ (ONS) population projection. This ensures that the aggregate population figures match the ONS estimate of the England population, and helps take account of the unregistered population. A full list of the indicative running costs allowances for each proposed CCG for 2013/14 can be seen on the NHS CBA website . CCG authorisation waves agreed The NHS Commissioning Board Authority is being asked to approve the timing of the four CCG authorisation waves. A paper going to its 31 May 2012 board meeting outlines how all 212 proposed CCG applicants have now agreed their authorisation wave and publishes the full set of four waves. Applications for CCG authorisation will take place from July to November 2012 and the NHS Commissioning Board is on schedule to have completed the authorisation process by January 2013. The wave process will comprise: 35 proposed CCGs in wave one; 70 in wave two; 67 in wave three; and 40 in wave four. The majority of proposed CCGs were able to secure their first choice of wave but, as applications for wave two exceeded availability, some were asked to move into an alternative. These moves were agreed between the proposed CCG and the SHA cluster. Proposed CCGs in each wave will continue to develop throughout the year as they take on increasing responsibilities and may have conditions set to enable them to prepare fully – irrespective of the wave they are in. All CCGs will take on their new commissioning duties, if authorised, on 1 April 2013. The Board Authority will continue to work with all proposed CCGs over the coming months, providing them with a comprehensive package of development and support to ensure they are in a strong position to take on their full responsibilities by April 2013. This will include: The applicants’ guide (published in April 2012) Regional authorisation ‘surgeries’ (see story below) A full data profile for their area An assessors’ guide A knowledge portal website Support materials and guidance The leadership development and assessment process. The authorisation process will ensure that CCGs are able to commission safely, to discharge responsibly their stewardship of the majority of the NHS budget, and to exercise their functions in relation to improving quality, reducing inequality and delivering improved health outcomes within the available resources. Each proposed CCG must develop a clear and credible commissioning plan for its local area to be able to progress through the authorisation process and become an authorised CCG. The full list of the proposed CCGs in each application wave can be seen on the NHS CBA website . CCG authorisation: Wave 1 workshops Two workshops are being held later this month for those proposed CCGs which are in the first wave of applications for authorisation. Up to four delegates from each emerging CCG are being invited to the day-long events on 28 May in London and 30 May in Leeds. Content at each session will cover the authorisation process in some detail, including how evidence will be assessed and decisions will be made; and identification of support. There will also be Q&A sessions and breakout sessions covering topics in more detail. All wave 1 applicants should have received an invite letter to the workshops. If not, they should contact their regional authorisation lead. Dates will be published shortly for similar workshops for those proposed CCGs in waves two, three and four. CCG authorisation: Recruitment of assessors The recruitment of assessors for the desktop review elements of the CCG authorisation process will begin this week. Their role will be to ensure that the evidence submitted by proposed CCGs is assessed transparently, consistently and fairly. NHS managers and clinicians with appropriate skills and experience in document assessment will be invited to apply via the NHS Commissioning Board Authority’s website soon. SHA clusters will be asked to co-ordinate the recruitment of assessors and assessors will receive training and accreditation before they start work, covering: their specific role and function within the CCG authorisation process the overarching principles, approach and methodology of the assessment process the key stages of assessment, and the requisite outputs of each stage the published domain definitions, criteria and authorisation thresholds as set out in the applicants’ guide and how to assess proposed CCGs’ evidence submissions against them. An Assessors’ Guide for the desktop review work which will be published shortly. It will be an accompaniment to Clinical commissioning group authorisation: Draft guide for applicants. Assessment centres and development process underway Further places are being released on a rolling basis for the CCG leadership assessment centres process and future CCG leaders are being encouraged to sign up if they haven’t already booked a place. Prospective CCG leaders are guaranteed a place that fits with their authorisation timetable, and the aim is to ensure that those who are shortlisted for a CCG leadership post, but have not been through an assessment centre, have the chance to do so. Individuals wishing to take part should complete the online preparatory work as soon as they are able, even if they don’t yet have a date for the assessment centre. The leadership assessment process got underway in March and there has been a high uptake of both the assessment centre places and the development offers. If anyone has any queries or needs assistance please contact the Hay Group helpline at NHSCCGassessment@haygroup.com or 0161 831 2478. Commissioning support services pass second stage of review Twenty three NHS commissioning support services will this week receive development plans which will outline the progress they need to make by August 2012. The plans will be followed up by discussions with the NHS Commissioning Board Authority during early June. The Board Authority published a report on 14 May about the overall outcome of the second stage in the business review process for commissioning support services (CSSs), known as ‘Checkpoint 2’, and the development plans are the final part of the process. The objective of Checkpoint 2 was to assess whether emerging CSSs are on a viable and secure path and have the ability to develop a full business plan by August 2012 when they will undertake the final checkpoint, prior to a decision on hosting arrangements by the Board Authority. Twenty five regional NHS commissioning support services and the nationwide NHS Communications and Engagement Service submitted outline business plans for Checkpoint 2 and 23 were given the go-ahead to proceed. The decisions were: Scenario A: CSS proceeds with medium to low issues as part of development plan South Yorkshire Staffordshire North West London Arden North Yorkshire and Humber Kent and Medway Merseyside Cheshire, Warrington and Wirral Norfolk and Waveney North East Central and East London West Yorkshire Best West (Somerset, Bristol, North Somerset and South Gloucestershire) CSS South (Southampton, Hampshire, Portsmouth and Isle of Wight) Scenario B: CSS proceeds with issues that need more rapid management Greater East Midlands Greater Manchester Cumbria and Lancashire Birmingham and Black Country Essex South London Surrey and Sussex Central Southern (Bucks, Oxfordshire, Berkshire, Gloucestershire and Swindon) Hertfordshire Scenario C: CSS stops West Mercia Peninsula (Devon and Cornwall) NHS Communications and Engagement Service The development plans will be binding and if the milestones in the plan are not met the Board Authority will review its support for the CSS. While CSSs are hosted by the Board Authority, it will be responsible for the financial risk. In the case of those CSSs which will not proceed beyond Checkpoint 2, the next steps will be: West Mercia and Peninsula – SHA clusters are working with local CCGs, primary care trust clusters and CSSs to develop new arrangements for both areas. NHS Communications and Engagement Service – See story below. The outcomes of the business review and assurance process for the ‘at scale’ commissioning support service offers will be published in June and be added to CSS development plans by the end of June. Communications and engagement commissioning support services Further to the story above, the next steps have been agreed to develop a revised operating model for communications and engagement services to support future commissioners. A ‘hub and spoke’ model – similar to that of the other ‘at scale’ CSSs – will be developed which links all CSS and CCGs across England, maps onto local engagement services, ensures staff are based appropriately in relation to local communities, and concentrates at scale work and additional communications expertise in a small number of hubs, not likely to exceed four to six. It is envisaged the model will incorporate local delivery teams and ‘at scale’ services delivered to a set of professional and measurable service standards through the commissioning support community. The next steps are: The setting up of an oversight group with CSS and CCG representation which will design the quality criteria and standards, develop the service lines, and develop a set of criteria that can be used to identify those services that can be done best at scale, and those more suited to local delivery. SHA Directors of Communications and Directors of Commissioning Development are asked to work with CSS leads and CCGs to undertake a rapid analysis and understanding of local communications and engagement services in their area, including those services offered by local authorities. Once the quality standards have been developed by the oversight group, SHA clusters will work with emerging CSS leaders to create proposals for the hub and spoke model. The aim is to do this in a coordinated way, which allows a very small number of CSSs to emerge as the hosts for the hubs, having worked in conjunction with the other CSS in their area in order to maintain local buy-in. CSSs will then be asked to express an interest in offering local and at scale services and bid to deliver communications and engagement services in a similar way to the other at scale services. This work will take place during June and July and a final decision will be made by the NHS Commissioning Board Authority in late July, ahead of the Checkpoint 3 process. The freedom of CCGs to choose their supplier of choice for commissioning support services, including communications and engagement, and the option to build or share support services in-house, remains as before and is unaffected by any proposed new operating model. Commissioning support: Informed customer events for CCGs Proposed CCG leaders are being encouraged to sign up for the ‘informed customer’ workshops which will help them determine what they need from commissioning support services. The workshops have been set up for 29 May in London and 7 June in Leeds and the programme and booking details are available online. The events will cover: Key issues and considerations for emerging CCGs on procuring CSS resources An update on the latest developments in commissioning support Feedback from the first real-time commissioning support simulation exercise involving six proposed CCGs and four CSSs Practical steps to help emerging CCGs plan their services The events are being run by the NHS Clinical Commissioners (NHS Alliance and NAPC) and Primary Care Commissioning on behalf of the NHS Commissioning Board Authority. NHS Commissioning Board: New appointments and organisational design The NHS Commissioning Board Authority announced the appointment of its final National Director and four Regional Directors earlier this month. They are: National Director for Patients and Information: Tim Kelsey, currently Executive Director of Transparency and Open Data for HM Government Regional Director, North of England: Richard Barker, currently Chief Operating Officer, NHS North of England Regional Director, Midlands and the East: Dr Paul Watson,currently Chief Executive, NHS Suffolk Regional Director, London: Dr Anne Rainsberry,currently Chief Executive, NHS North West London and Deputy Chief Executive, NHS London Regional Director, South of England: Andrea Young,currently Chief Operating Officer / Deputy Chief Executive, NHS South of England The four Regional Directors will be part of the senior leadership team of the Operations Directorate, reporting directly to the Chief Operating Officer. They are working with primary care trusts, strategic health authorities and other stakeholders to co-design a proposal for the final model of the Commissioning Board’s network of local area teams. An update will be given at the Board meeting on 31 May. The Operations Directorate is now using the term ‘regions’ instead of ‘sectors’ and ‘local area teams’ instead of ‘local offices’ – and there will be fewer than the 50 that were initially proposed. Each team will have the same core functions around CCG development and assurance; emergency planning, resilience, and response; the strategic assurance of quality and patient safety locally; partnerships; service transformation and configuration and oversight of the local NHS and care system. There will be variations in the scope of their direct commissioning responsibilities as follows: All local area teams will have responsibilities for GP, dental and pharmacy services Around one-third of the teams will lead on specialised commissioning A smaller number of teams will have responsibilities for optometric, military health and offender health services. The commissioning of some public health services is likely to be done to a larger geography than local area teams (for example screening programmes) while others are likely to be done at local area team level (for example public health services for the under 5s). Any qualified provider From 2013-14 CCGs will be able to decide when, where, and how to use competition to drive up quality, enable innovation and improve services. They will be able to choose the service areas to which patient choice of provider will be extended locally, based on local needs and priorities and informed by engagement with patients and clinicians. With this in mind, earlier this week a group of proposed CCG leaders took part in a national event to demonstrate how Any Qualified Provider (AQP) forms part of the commissioners’ toolkit and can be used – along with other forms of procurement – to improve services for patients and enable innovation. Delegates explored the opportunities and challenges of extending patient choice of AQP from 2013 onwards, and how this would help them prepare for authorisation. The day focused on key themes such as: Why and when to use patient choice of AQP What commissioning support will CCGs need AQP qualification: how to assure quality and patient safety Addressing concerns about service fragmentation, demand management and price setting GPs as providers: can they be part of AQP In addition, PCT clusters are on track to deliver the NHS Operating Framework 2012-13 requirement to offer patients choice of AQP in at least three services in line with local priorities in 2012-13. Commissioners have identified a range of 28 different services and the vast majority of commissioners have already committed to offering choice in at least three services by September 2012. A number of PCTs have also engaged further with CCGs, aiming to better reflect CCG priorities for the future. Payment by results: a new guide Payment by Results (PbR) is the payment system in England under which commissioners pay healthcare providers for each patient seen or treated. Activity covered by PbR tariffs and currencies covers an increasing proportion of commissioner spend on acute healthcare. It is essential that clinical commissioning groups (CCGs), commissioning support services (CSSs) and local clinical leads have an understanding of PbR. For newcomers, this simple guide is a good place to start. For more information go to http://healthandcare.dh.gov.uk/payment-by-results/ Free places offered to CCGs at commissioning conferences The NHS Commissioning Board Authority will have a presence at two major conferences next month – the NHS Confederation annual conference and exhibition in Manchester on 20-22 June and the Commissioning Show 2012 in London on 27-28 June. As well as an exhibition stand at each event, there will also be a number of speakers and workshops to guide delegates through the essential commissioning reforms taking place this year. Both events are also offering special deals to proposed CCGs. The NHS Confederation is offering one free conference pass to each CCG when they register with the NHS Confederation. Call 0844 800 5987 or email annualconference2012@nhsconfed.org to book your place. Meanwhile in partnership with the NHS Alliance and the NAPC, there is also a limited allocation of free passes for CCGs for the Commissioning Show. Send an e-mail with ‘BOOK COMM 12’ in the subject line to a.andrews@closerstillmedia.com to book your place. Comments on this page are now closed. Share: Tweet

pages.title: Proposed CCG configuration and member practices published | NHS England
pages.content: The NHS Commissioning Board Authority has published the proposed configuration and member practices for 212 proposed CCGs for the first time. This is a major step forward in the work to establish the new clinical commissioning landscape by April 2013, and, along with the publication of the running cost allowances, will enable proposed CCGs to further develop their organisation ready for authorisation and establishment. The information is in a paper for the Board Authority which will be asked to agree the proposed configuration as the basis of authorisation at its board meeting on 31 May 2012. National and regional CCG maps displaying the information are also available. The paper confirms that there are now proposed CCGs covering the whole of England and includes the detailed geographic areas for each for the first time, plus the planning assumptions about the member practices in each proposed CCG (using April 2011 data). This means that everyone living in England will be covered by a CCG from April 2013. These planning assumptions will allow work to progress. Once the NHS Commissioning Board is established as a statutory body, it will check that legal requirements have been met and approve the final details of geography, names and member practices of CCGs through the authorisation process. Each proposed CCG has determined its own configuration within the framework set out by the Board Authority, which ensures that: there is sign up from member practices there is appropriate geographical coverage that allows a proposed CCG to take on responsibility for commissioning for a population where a proposed CCG straddles upper tier or unitary local authority boundaries, it is for patient interest reasons each proposed CCG is a viable organisation in terms of the degree of sharing of roles and functions, or the use of commissioning support that it will need to consider Dame Barbara Hakin, National Director of Commissioning Development at the NHS Commissioning Board Authority, said, “This is a real landmark moment and is a credit to everyone involved in developing CCGs and the new clinically-led commissioning system. “We should not underestimate the hard work that has taken place to get us where we are and the huge progress that has been made across the country. We have proposed CCGs covering the whole of England. We have 212 groups of practices who have chosen to come together to shape and commission services to deliver better care, better experience, better outcomes and improved safety for their local populations. “There is still a great deal of work to do as the proposed CCGs move closer to authorisation, but we should take a moment to celebrate this fantastic achievement.” List of proposed CCGs with names, populations, current PCTs and running cost allowances List of proposed CCGs with proposed known constituent member practices See the national and regional maps of proposed CCGs . Comments on this page are now closed. Share: Tweet

pages.title: National Director for Patients and Information appointed | NHS England
pages.content: The NHS Commissioning Board Authority has today completed the recruitment of its national leadership team with the appointment of Tim Kelsey as National Director for Patients and Information. Tim is currently Executive Director of Transparency and Open Data for HM Government where he has been responsible for government policy on transparency and open government. Previously, he was responsible for the design and launch of NHS Choices – the online NHS information service. Chief Executive of the NHS Commissioning Board Authority, Sir David Nicholson said: “I’m delighted to welcome Tim as the final member of our National Director team. Tim comes to the Board Authority with a vast range of experience and expertise, which I know will ensure that the patient voice is at the very heart of everything that we do”. Tim said: “I am thrilled to be joining the NHS Commissioning Board Authority. As a new organisation, we have a huge opportunity to be truly patient-focused and clinically-led and work in new and innovative ways to deliver real improvements in patient outcomes and experience.” The completed team of National Directors appointed to the NHS Commissioning Board Authority is as follows: Chief Nursing Officer – Jane Cummings Chief Operating Officer – Ian Dalton Chief of Staff – Jo-Anne Wass Director of Commissioning Development – Dame Barbara Hakin Director of Finance – Paul Baumann Director of Transformation – Jim Easton Director for Patients and Information – Tim Kelsey Director of Policy, Corporate Development and Partnership – Bill McCarthy Medical Director – Sir Bruce Keogh Board appointments will transfer to the NHS Commissioning Board once it is established as an Executive Non Departmental Public Body in October 2012. Follow Tim Kelsey on twitter @tkelsey1 Comments on this page are now closed. Share: Tweet

pages.title: Checkpoint 2 customer survey  | NHS England
pages.content: The report of a customer survey, which was carried out with proposed clinical commissioning groups (CCGs) and NHS commissioning support services (CSSs) has been published today. The findings show that the over 90% of proposed CCGs are very or quite confident that the arrangements they are putting in place for commissioning support will allow them to achieve authorisation. Just over a half say they expect to source at least 50% of their commissioning support through NHS CSSs, with around a further quarter sourcing 30%-49%. The report also suggests that the majority of CCGs intend to carry on with the same CSS during 2012/13, with one in ten wanting to exercise choice; although they do want more information on choice and advice on how to access procure support. Although the findings suggest that more could be done to ensure CSS objectives are aligned to those of the CCGs they will support, most proposed CCGs say they feel engaged with, and involved in, the development of their local CSS. The survey was conducted in March and April 2012 as part of the arrangements to support the second stage in the business review process for CSSs, known as Checkpoint 2. The outcome of Checkpoint 2 was published on 14 May and the 23 NHS CSSs which are progressing through to Checkpoint 3 will this week receive their development plans which outline the progress they will need to make by August 2012. Overall, the Checkpoint 2 process found that CSSs had good leadership and good levels of engagement in developing their customer focus, but a need to further develop their business focus. Milestones in the plans will be agreed at meetings with the Board Authority in May and June. These will be binding and each CSS will have monthly progress check with the Board Authority. Joe Rafferty, Director of Commissioning Support, said: “The commissioning support survey results have been taken account of and work is already well underway to address the points that were identified. Overall, we know from Checkpoint 2 that CSSs are on track, but clearly there are some key areas – such as supporting those CCGs which want to exercise their choice of commissioning support, and ensuring CSSs provide greater innovation – which need further development.” CSS managing directors are due to be appointed from late June and will further strengthen the CSS leadership teams. The survey was led by the Clinical Commissioning Coalition (comprising the National Association of Primary Care and the NHS Alliance) on behalf of the NHS Commissioning Board Authority to provide an independent view of how the services and the relationships between emerging CSSs and CCGs are developing. Independent research agency TNS-BRMB carried out the work. The survey was sent to all proposed CCGs, with a 66 per cent response rate. All 25 CSSs included in Checkpoint 2 took part. Download the report here . Share: Tweet

pages.title: Commissioning Support Bulletin – Issue 2, 28 May 2012 | NHS England
pages.content: Contents CSS Learning Network engages with Sir David Nicholson and Dame Barbara Hakin Recruitment of managing directors for CSSs CCG indicative running cost allowances CSS development plans Next steps for communications and engagement services Update on the ‘at scale’ offers Key learnings from simulation exercise Checkpoint 2 customer survey published Checkpoint 3 design and guidance NHS Commissioning Board: New appointments and organisational design News in brief Welcome to the second monthly Commissioning Support Bulletin from the NHS Commissioning Board Authority. This month I’m pleased to say we’ve got the chance to hear from Sir David Nicholson and Dame Barbara Hakin as well as updates on the Checkpoint 2 commissioning support service (CSS) development plans, the future for communications and engagement services, and the external recruitment process for the important CSS managing director posts. We’ve also got more information on the CCG running costs allowances and how these are calculated. Of course, the outcome of Checkpoint 2 has been a huge milestone for all of us and I’m sure many of you are still taking the full implications on board. Every CSS will this week receive a development plan and these will help to focus our approach and provide a route map for the next steps to Checkpoint 3. Of course, it is a massive challenge to complete the necessary steps by August but we should approach our task with confidence. We took the serious step of stopping three CSSs in Checkpoint 2 and this will have been difficult news for the people in those organisations. I wish again to reassure those staff who are affected that there will still be a significant need for locally-based staff to deliver support services to clinical commissioning groups (CCGs). The main impact will be to senior management arrangements and organisation shape rather than to the roles that are available to NHS staff. We will shortly to be able to update you on the new arrangements forWest MerciaandPeninsula; and the senior communications leaders, who have done such a great job in defining much of the model for communications, are already working with local CSS leaders on how to build this model into CSS arrangements. The coming months are absolutely critical – there is a lot to manage and no room for complacency. Nevertheless I am optimistic. The landscape is changing and there is a huge opportunity for CSSs to prove themselves to potential customers. Thank you again for taking part so constructively in the process. Please keep in touch and let us know what you think. To send us your comments, or join our mailing list, please contact us at commissioningsupport@dh.gsi.gov.uk Dr Joe Rafferty Director of Commissioning Support CSS Learning Network engages with Sir David Nicholson and Dame Barbara Hakin CSS leaders met with Sir David Nicholson and Dame Barbara Hakin at the monthly CSS Learning Network meeting, run by the NHS Commissioning Board Authority, on24 May 2012. The Board Authority Chief Executive and National Director for Commissioning Development listened to the views of CSS leaders and answered key questions on the future form of CSSs and the transition to the Board Authority. In the session Sir David emphasised that CSSs were “critical to the success of the new clinical commissioning system” and highlighted that the current private sector market was unlikely to be able to provide more than around five per cent of the support that would be needed initially, before thanking CSSs for their work so far. He said: “The real work starts now and the key focus must be on developing new and effective ways to deliver high quality NHS services. We need to have a fully-functioning, dynamic commissioning support sector in place.” Sir David also emphasised the importance of communications and engagement commissioning support services, which would help with coordination across the whole commissioning system. He said: “We will be seeking a new business model that provides appropriate connectivity across the system based in common NHS values, principles and behaviours.” On the future form of CSSs he said the Board Authority would be guided by CSSs and that a range of models including social enterprises and joint ventures would be explored. Sir David also told CSSs how impressed he had been with the CCG survey which highlighted CCGs’ appreciation of their services. Dame Barbara highlighted the “remarkable journey” that CSSs were on and said the Checkpoint 2 process had shown they were doing a “fantastic job” in creating viable organisations. She said: “We are about to see a significant step forward as CSSs implement their development plans and permanent leaders are appointed. The success of the new system is as dependent on these organisations as it is on CCGs and we must set the bar high for these senior appointments.” She said that CSSs would operate at arms-length from day-to-day Board Authority business, and that every attempt would be made to make the units feel as autonomous as possible. Dame Barbara also commended the CSSs on their increasingly good relationships with CCGs, and added that she was hearing increasingly from local authorities that they felt more positive about joint working. Mike Farrar, Chief Executive of the NHS Confederation, also attended the network meeting and discussed with the CSS leaders how the NHS Confederation could provide support to their learning network. Recruitment of managing directors for CSSs The assessment centres for the CSS managing director posts will start on 29 May and run for three days. Interviews will follow in mid-June and appointments will be made from later that month. Now that the first recruitment phase has reached the shortlist stage, the external recruitment phase will begin and a national job advertisement is due to appear shortly. The appointments will be made by a panel chaired by Dame Barbara Hakin, National Managing Director for Commissioning Development at the NHS Commissioning Board Authority, as CSSs will be hosted by the Board Authority for up to three years. The next level of recruitment will be led by CSS managing directors. CCG indicative running cost allowances The NHS Commissioning Board Authority has published the indicative running cost allowances for 212 proposed CCGs for 2013-14 in a paper for the Board Authority’s board meeting on 31 May. The running costs allowance for CCGs has already been set at up to £25 per head of population per year. This limit meets the requirement to reduce system wide administration costs by one third, and ensures spending on running costs is kept to a reasonable level and NHS funding is focused on providing high quality services for patients and the public. The Board Authority has decided that the fairest approach to calculating running costs allowances for CCGs is to base them on the GP registered lists for practices within the CCG but moderated at local authority level to match the Office for National Statistics’ (ONS) population projections. This ensures that the aggregate population figures match the ONS estimate of theEnglandpopulation, and helps take account of the unregistered population. The latest ONS projections for 2013 are for a totalEnglandpopulation of 53.56m. The attribution data set (ADS), which is the source of GP list data, gives a patient population of 55.26m for practices inEnglandin April 2011. The starting point for the calculation of running costs is the patient populations for aCCG’s GP practices as recorded in the ADS. This ensures that the distribution of running costs takes account of cross-boundary patient flows. It was estimated that 3.4m registered patients are not resident in the area for which their CCG has geographic responsibility. A methodology was needed to adjust these patient populations, so that together they reconcile back to the ONS England population projection of 53.56m. As a result, the total ADS population resident in each district local authority area was matched to the ONS projection for 2013 (after excluding estimated counts of military personnel). This is consistent with a long-established methodology used in PCT financial allocations. The methodology also takes account of factors such as inaccurate lists, for instance where patients no longer live in the area and are registered with a different practice, but have not yet been removed from their previous GP’s list. A full list of the indicative running costs allowances for each proposed CCG for 2013-14 and the briefing note can both be found on the Board Authority’s website. CSS development plans The 23 NHS CSSs will this week receive development plans which outline the progress they will need to make by August 2012. Milestones in the plans will be agreed at meetings with the NHS Commissioning Board Authority during May and early June. The milestones will be binding and each CSS will have a monthly progress check with the Board Authority. If the milestones in the plan are not met the Board Authority will review its support for the CSS. Overall, the Checkpoint 2 process found that CSSs had: Good levels of leadership Good levels of engagement in developing their customer focus A need to further develop their business focus in line with the financial information being worked up. The Board Authority published a report on 14 May about the overall outcome of the second stage in the business review process for CSSs, known as Checkpoint 2, and the development plans are the final part of the checkpoint. At Checkpoint 2, key areas of strength were identified as: Established leadership team with a shared vision A clearly separated organisation, well into its transition phase, with a detailed organisational development programme Developing operational structure Matured / impressive engagement with CCG clinicians and managers Service level agreements (SLAs) in place, and developing service levels Developing customer performance monitoring Senior commercial skills in place Detailed competitor analysis and developing marketing strategy Main risks identified and mitigated. Areas for focus and development included: Insufficient management and/or commitment Need for an in-depth plan and a greater sense of pace Concern over the ‘right-size’ for the business Lack of engagement with customers Memorandums of understanding but not SLAs in place CCGs’ lack of confidence in CSSs Costs unclear and lack of a pricing structure Margins unclear (income / service line) External help – only now specifying. In the case of those CSSs which will not proceed beyond Checkpoint 2 –West MerciaandPeninsula– local CCGs are in discussions with the Board Authority, SHA clusters and surrounding CSSs and a new configuration will be agreed during June. The outcomes of the business review and assurance process for the ‘at scale’ commissioning support service offers will be published in June and be added to CSS development plans by the end of June. As part of the development planning process, key areas for leadership, board and organisational development have also been identified, and a wider programme of support is being created. The objective of Checkpoint 2 was to assess whether emerging CSSs are on a viable and secure path and have the ability to develop a full business plan by August 2012 when they will undertake the final checkpoint, prior to a decision on hosting arrangements by the Board Authority. Next steps for communications and engagement services Next steps have been agreed which will ensure the development of a revised operating model for communications and engagement services in line with the timescales for the business review and assurance process. A ‘hub and spoke’ model – similar to that of the other ‘at scale’ CSSs – will be developed which links all CSSs and CCGs across England, maps onto local engagement services, ensures staff are based appropriately in relation to local communities, and concentrates at scale work and additional communications expertise in a small number of hubs, not likely to exceed four to six. It is envisaged the model will incorporate local delivery teams and ‘at scale’ services delivered to a set of professional and measurable service standards through the commissioning support community. The next steps are: The setting up of an oversight group with CSS and CCG representation which will design the quality criteria and standards, develop the service lines, and develop a set of criteria that can be used to identify those services that can be done best at scale, and those more suited to local delivery. Once the quality standards have been developed by the oversight group, SHA clusters to work with emerging CSS leaders to create proposals for the hub and spoke model. The aim is to do this in a coordinated way, which allows a very small number of CSSs to emerge as the hosts for the hubs, having worked in conjunction with the other CSSs in their area in order to maintain local buy-in. SHA Directors of Communications and Directors of Commissioning Development working with CSS and CCG leaders to undertake a rapid analysis and understanding of local communications and engagement services in their area, including those services offered by local authorities. CSSs to be asked to express an interest in offering local and at scale services and bid to deliver communications and engagement services in a similar way to the other at scale services. This work will take place during June and July and a final decision will be made by the NHS Commissioning Board Authority in late July, ahead of the Checkpoint 3 process. Update on the ‘at scale’ offers CSSs are currently preparing their responses to the standards set out by the NHS Commissioning Board Authority for business intelligence integration and validation centres and healthcare (clinical) procurement services. In addition CSSs will provide information on business support services setting out how they propose to benchmark with the wider market. By 8 June each CSS must submit detailed proposals for the at scale services it wishes to provide according to the Board Authority’s criteria and standards. CSSs which plan to offer business intelligence, healthcare (clinical) procurement and business support components to their customers are subject to additional tests in May and June 2012, following the Checkpoint 2 assurance process. These CSSs have already set out their working assumptions for these components within their outline business plans. By the end of June, the Board Authority will have reviewed the CSSs’ submissions and identified the final configuration and development plans. Key learnings from simulation exercise Positive feedback has been gained from the first real-time commissioning support simulation exercise which took place on 17 May. The event, which involving six emerging CCGs and four CSSs, and was organised by the NHS Commissioning Board Authority with the Health Services Management Centre at the University of Birmingham and NHS Clinical Commissioners, was well attended. It created a realistic environment in which participants, through role play, explored the ways that emerging CCGs will work with CSSs to commission effectively from their providers. A full report is being prepared and will be published in June. In the meantime, the key learnings from the day were: Relationship development: CSSs and CCGs need to be clear and proactive about what is on offer, and make time to expand networks and the understanding of others’ roles and responsibilities. Collaboration and competition: Important to collaborate but also a need to be clear about the legal rules, for instance regarding procurement, governance, and accountability. CCGs and CSSs need to maximise the benefits of clinically led commissioning by knowing when clinical involvement is essential, and when other members of the commissioning family have the expertise to take it from here. Key learnings from the independent sector need to be identified and shared. For instance, longer term planning, ‘future gazing’, customer focus, and approaches to risk management. Contingency planning is important as is delivering the ‘business as usual’. The emerging CCGs and CSSs were invited to reflect a range of sizes, locations and stages of development and included: CCGs inBristol,Cheshire, Cambridgeshire andPeterborough,Enfield, Mid-Sussex and Horsham, and South ofTees CSSs in North West London,East Midlands, andSouthampton, Hampshire,Isle of WightandPortsmouth; plus a team of independent sector commissioning support service providers. Two informed customer workshops will take place on 29 May in London and 7 June in Leeds and the outputs from these will be published in due course. Checkpoint 2 customer survey The report of a customer survey, which was carried out with proposed clinical commissioning groups (CCGs) and NHS commissioning support services (CSSs) has been published. The findings show that the over 90% of proposed CCGs are very or quite confident that the arrangements they are putting in place for commissioning support will allow them to achieve authorisation. Just over a half say they expect to source at least 50% of their commissioning support through NHS CSSs, with around a further quarter sourcing 30%-49%. The report also suggests that the majority of CCGs intend to carry on with the same CSS during 2012-13, with one in ten wanting to exercise choice; although they do want more information on choice and advice on how to access procure support. Although the findings suggest that more could be done to ensure CSS objectives are aligned to those of the CCGs they will support, most proposed CCGs say they feel engaged with, and involved in, the development of their local CSS. The survey was conducted in March and April 2012 as part of the arrangements to support the second stage in the business review process for CSSs, known as Checkpoint 2. The outcome of Checkpoint 2 was published on 14 May and the 23 NHS CSSs which are progressing through to Checkpoint 3 will this week receive their development plans which outline the progress they will need to make by August 2012. Overall, the Checkpoint 2 process found that CSSs had good leadership and good levels of engagement in developing their customer focus, but a need to further develop their business focus. In a statement on the Board Authority’s website, Joe Rafferty, Director of Commissioning Support, said: “The commissioning support survey results have been taken account of and work is already well underway to address the points that were identified. Overall, we know from Checkpoint 2 that CSSs are on track, but clearly there are some key areas – such as supporting those CCGs which want to exercise their choice of commissioning support, and ensuring CSSs provide greater innovation – which need further development.” The survey was led by the Clinical Commissioning Coalition (comprising the National Association of Primary Care and the NHS Alliance) on behalf of the NHS Commissioning Board Authority to provide an independent view of how the services and the relationships between emerging CSSs and CCGs are developing. Independent research agency TNS-BRMB carried out the work. The survey was sent to all proposed CCGs, with a 66 per cent response rate. All 25 CSSs included in Checkpoint 2 took part. A copy of the survey report can be seen on the Board Authority’s website . Checkpoint 3 design and guidance The design for Checkpoint 3 design is being finalised and the guidance is due out in early June. This checkpoint will include the fourth domain – delivery – and the key governance and finance regimes. Work is also progressing on the CSS performance dashboard for agreement and implementation this summer. NHS Commissioning Board: New appointments and organisational design The NHS Commissioning Board Authority announced the appointment of its final National Director and four Regional Directors earlier this month. They are: National Director for Patients and Information Tim Kelsey currently Executive Director of Transparency and Open Data for HM Government Regional Director, North ofEngland Richard Barker currently Chief Operating Officer, NHS North of England Regional Director,Midlandsand the East Dr Paul Watson currently Chief Executive, NHS Suffolk Regional Director,London Dr Anne Rainsberry currently Chief Executive, NHS North West London and Deputy Chief Executive, NHS London Regional Director, South ofEngland Andrea Young currently Chief Operating Officer / Deputy Chief Executive, NHS South of Englan The four Regional Directors will be part of the senior leadership team of the Operations Directorate, reporting directly to the Chief Operating Officer Ian Dalton. They are working with primary care trusts, strategic health authorities and other stakeholders to co-design a proposal for the final model of the Commissioning Board’s network of local area teams. An update on these will be given at the Board Authority’s board meeting on 31 May. The Board Authority is now using the term ‘regions’ instead of ‘sectors’ and ‘local area teams’ instead of ‘local offices’ – and there will be fewer than the 50 that were initially proposed. Each team will have the same core functions around CCG development and assurance; emergency planning, resilience, and response; the strategic assurance of quality and patient safety locally; partnerships; service transformation and configuration; and oversight of the local NHS and care system. There will be variations in the scope of their direct commissioning responsibilities as follows: All local area teams will have responsibilities for GP, dental and pharmacy services Around one-third of the teams will lead on specialised commissioning A smaller number of teams will have responsibilities for optometric, military health and offender health services. The commissioning of some public health services is likely to be done to a larger geography than local area teams (for example screening programmes) while others are likely to be done at local area team level (for example public health services for the under fives). News in brief The Business Plan for the NHS Commissioning Board Authority is due to be published this week. The document sets out what the Board Authority will continue to do in the establishment phase up to October 2012 when it is scheduled to become an executive non-departmental public body. As part of authorisation, CCGs will be required to demonstrate that they have appropriate plans in place to procure support services by 2016. The NHS Commissioning Board Authority is producing a number of products that will provide CCGs with the tools necessary to understand procurement, available options for obtaining support, and statutory obligations. These products will form part of a consultation exercise with CCGs due to take place from the summer. To embed the underlying principles, a series of events for CCGs will also be set up. Information has been released in the last week about the configuration and authorisation applications for proposed CCGs. For more updates about this, read our latest Bulletin for proposed CCGs . Comments on this page are now closed. Share: Tweet

pages.title: Landmark moment on the road to authorisation – Barbara Hakin | NHS England
pages.content: Last week we reached a real landmark moment in the journey towards developing CCGs and the new clinically-led commissioning system. As you will have heard, we now have proposed CCGs covering the whole of England. That means 212 groups of practices have chosen to come together to shape and commission services to deliver better care, better experience, better outcomes and improved safety for their local populations. We shouldn’t underestimate the hard work that has taken place to get us where we are and the huge progress that has been made across the country, but there is still a great deal to do – and I’m sure the pace is the same where you are. Our focus continues to be on shaping the new commissioning system so that it’s ready to go live from April 2013. There’s a great deal to be done collectively to prepare for this and I know from my conversations with GPs and CCG leaders recently that clinical commissioning groups are really keen to make best use of this transitional year to move to the new arrangements. Proposed CCGs are now firmly on their journeys to become fully fledged statutory organisations – made up of, and accountable to, their member practices. Authorisation is the important first step in this journey, so firstly I want to draw your attention to the draft guide for applicants for proposed CCGs which the Board Authority has published. As we’ve said all along, we wanted to make the authorisation process developmental for clinicians, while at the same time balancing it with the need to monitor public funds and ensure the safety and quality of local health services for our patients. I really do think we’ve achieved this and – with many CCGs’ help and input – reached our goal of a rigorous but fair process. I’m sure you’ve seen the document already, but if not, the draft guide provides a detailed description of the criteria, thresholds and evidence for authorisation. It sets out the timetable for applications in four waves – the first of which is only a couple of months away, starting in July. The guide is designed to help proposed CCGs prepare that application by working with their member practices, and then help them develop clear plans to progress through to become authorised CCGs. I know from speaking to aspiring CCG leaders over the last few weeks that many are already planning for the authorisation process and others are keen to do so, therefore I thought it might be useful to set out some of the logical steps that proposed CCGs can take now. They have already agreed – along with their SHA cluster – which ‘wave’ of authorisation they will be part of – and this information has also been released. We were delighted to see that so many CCGs wanted to be in wave 1, but please remember that there’s no advantage or disadvantage to being part of any particular wave – all CCGs will take on their new commissioning duties, if authorised, on 1 April 2013. Next, as CCGs begin to prepare for authorisation, I’d also ask them to take the time to ensure they establish sound governance arrangements, have a constitution, nominate leaders for the key roles on their governing bodies and keep all their member practices informed of the process. The next few months will be so important as we move through this process and the way the Board Authority continues to engage with and support emerging CCGs will be critical. Again, if you’re not already aware, there’s a great deal of tailored support available and we’ll be producing more in the coming weeks. We want to see a network of successful, sustainable, authorised CCGs ready to be the best they can be for their patients and populations from April 2013. Comments on this page are now closed. Share: Tweet

pages.title: NHS England » Board meeting – 31 May 2012
pages.content: 24 May 2012 - 15:08 We hold our board meetings in public in the interests of openness and transparency in our decision making. The next public board meeting will take place, at the Birmingham University Edgbaston campus, on Thursday 31 st May 2012 from 10.30am to 1.00pm in the: Nicolson Building (next to) Winterbourne House & Botanical Gardens 58 Edgbaston Park Road Birmingham B15 2RT This is location G12 on the downloadable map . The Nicolson building is about 10 minutes by cab from Birmingham New Street train station and free parking is provided onsite which will be clearly marked in front of the conference building. See also the website for the venue . Registration at the event starts from 10am. If you would like to attend, please register your interest as places are limited. Please contact commissioningboard@nhs.net or call Finn Dudaniec, by 12 noon on Wednesday 30th May, on 0113 254 6550. Please note that members of the public are welcome to attend meetings of the Board – which although being held in public are not public meetings. Questions submitted via this website won’t be passed on for discussion at Board meetings but will receive a response. The board meeting will be broadcast live as part of our commitment to make information as accessible as possible. The livestream is best viewed in Firefox , Google Chrome or Internet Explorer 8 and 9 with the latest version of Adobe Flash Player . You may experience issues viewing this content in Internet Explorer 6 and 7. View a recording of the board meeting on Ustream A separate recording of each agenda item is also available. You can view the agenda and board papers below. Board meeting agenda Item 1 – Minutes from previous meeting Decisions of the public Board meeting held 31 May 2012 Board papers Item 2 – NHS Commissioning Board programme update Item 3 – Update on end state running cost position of the NHS Commissioning Board 2013-14 and 2014-15 Item 4 – Design of the NHS operations directorate Item 5 – Emerging clinical commissioning group configuration: names, geography and constituent members Annex 1: List of emerging CCG names to be put forward for authorisation along with indicative running cost allowance Annex 2: Clinical commissioning groups in England proposed geographic boundaries Annex 3: CCGs confirmed for waves 1, 2, 3 and 4 for authorisation List of proposed known constituent member practices within each proposed CCG (data taken from April 2011) Comments on this page are now closed. pages.title: NHS England » Clinical commissioning groups: proposed configurations agreed
pages.content: The board of the NHS Commissioning Board Authority has today agreed the proposed configuration and member practices for 212 proposed clinical commissioning groups (CCGs). This information, along with the publication of the indicative running cost allowances for 2013/14, will enable proposed CCGs to develop their organisations ready for authorisation and establishment in April 2103. There are now proposed CCGs covering the whole of England. Once the NHS Commissioning Board is established as a statutory body, it will check that legal requirements have been met and approve the final details of geography, names and member practices of each CCG through the authorisation process. Every proposed CCG has now agreed a place in one of four application waves for authorisation. Those in wave 1 will begin their applications in July 2012. Download the list of proposed CCGs with names, populations and indicative running cost allowances (this document is now available on our archived website ) Download the list of proposed CCGs with proposed known constituent member practices (data taken from April 2011) (this document is now available on our archived website ) Read the list of proposed CCGs within each application wave for authorisation See the maps of proposed CCGs in England Please note: The organisational codes contained within these files are provisional as provided by the Organisation Data Service (ODS). These codes are currently under review and may change in the future. Further information about the release of CCG data by Organisation Data Service (ODS) can be found on the ODS web pages. Comments on this page are now closed. Topics Commissioning

pages.title: NHS England » Proposed CCG configuration and member practices published
pages.content: 24 May 2012 - 14:32 The NHS Commissioning Board Authority has published the proposed configuration and member practices for 212 proposed CCGs for the first time. This is a major step forward in the work to establish the new clinical commissioning landscape by April 2013, and, along with the publication of the running cost allowances, will enable proposed CCGs to further develop their organisation ready for authorisation and establishment. The information is in a paper for the Board Authority which will be asked to agree the proposed configuration as the basis of authorisation at its board meeting on 31 May 2012. National and regional CCG maps displaying the information are also available. The paper confirms that there are now proposed CCGs covering the whole of England and includes the detailed geographic areas for each for the first time, plus the planning assumptions about the member practices in each proposed CCG (using April 2011 data). This means that everyone living in England will be covered by a CCG from April 2013. These planning assumptions will allow work to progress. Once the NHS Commissioning Board is established as a statutory body, it will check that legal requirements have been met and approve the final details of geography, names and member practices of CCGs through the authorisation process. Each proposed CCG has determined its own configuration within the framework set out by the Board Authority, which ensures that: there is sign up from member practices there is appropriate geographical coverage that allows a proposed CCG to take on responsibility for commissioning for a population where a proposed CCG straddles upper tier or unitary local authority boundaries, it is for patient interest reasons each proposed CCG is a viable organisation in terms of the degree of sharing of roles and functions, or the use of commissioning support that it will need to consider Dame Barbara Hakin, National Director of Commissioning Development at the NHS Commissioning Board Authority, said, “This is a real landmark moment and is a credit to everyone involved in developing CCGs and the new clinically-led commissioning system. “We should not underestimate the hard work that has taken place to get us where we are and the huge progress that has been made across the country. We have proposed CCGs covering the whole of England. We have 212 groups of practices who have chosen to come together to shape and commission services to deliver better care, better experience, better outcomes and improved safety for their local populations. “There is still a great deal of work to do as the proposed CCGs move closer to authorisation, but we should take a moment to celebrate this fantastic achievement.” List of proposed CCGs with names, populations, current PCTs and running cost allowances List of proposed CCGs with proposed known constituent member practices See the national and regional maps of proposed CCGs . Comments on this page are now closed.
