pages.title: Health Education England’s inaugural Board meeting | Health Education England
pages.content: Health Education England’s inaugural Board meeting took place on 28 June. All of our board meetings are open to the public and the agenda items are published five days in advance. You are welcome to attend the board meetings as an observer, but need to inform us in advance. Please note that space is restricted so places will be allocated on a first come first served basis. As an observer you are not entitled to participate or ask questions. From time to time the Board may need to consider agenda items which are confidential and cannot be discussed in public. If this is the case, a private session will be held, from which the public will be excluded. 28 June Board papers Health Education England Board Meeting Agenda HEE01 Appointment of Chief Executive HEE 02 Governance Structure and Board arrangements HEE 02a Standing Orders HEE 02b Standing Financial Instructions HEE 02c Codes of Conduct and Accountability HEE 02d Scheme of Delegation HEE HEE 02e Scheme of Delegation Local Education and Training … HEE 02f Conflicts of Interest Policy HEE 03 Freedom of Information and Publication scheme HEE 04 Framework Agreement HEE 05 Developing Heath Education England’s Strategy HEE 05a Introducing Health Education England HEE 06 A commitment to the NHS Constitution HEE 06a NHS Constitution All queries relating to attendance at Board meetings should be directed to: Sophie Herd (email: hee.enquiries@nhs.net ) Health Education England Transition Team, Department of Health, Room 2N15, Quarry House, Quarry Hill, Leeds, LS2 7UE. Tweet No related posts.

pages.title: Ian Cumming confirmed as Chief Executive of Health Education England | Health Education England
pages.content: Ian Cumming has been confirmed as the first Chief Executive of Health Education England (HEE). From its establishment on 28 June, HEE will provide national leadership to the new system of education and training in healthcare. This new system will give employers greater responsibility and accountability for planning and developing the workforce, within a national framework that is professionally informed and underpinned by strong academic links. Sir Keith Pearson, Chair of HEE, said: “I am delighted to announce Ian Cumming as Chief Executive of Health Education England. Ian has extensive experience as a leader in the NHS and will bring a compelling sense of vision and purpose to HEE.” Una O’Brien, Permanent Secretary, said: “Ian Cumming brings a wealth of experience to this important role. HEE will need to establish itself quickly so it can take on its new responsibilities. I am confident that Ian will lead the way to establish effective leadership and governance for the organisation and ensure early and successful relationships with key partners and stakeholders. “I would like to thank Christine Outram for the leadership she has provided as the Senior Responsible Officer for setting up HEE. Christine has played a key role in helping to shape plans for HEE in the preparatory phase before it is established as a Special Health Authority.” On his appointment, Ian Cumming said: “We have a great opportunity to shape a future healthcare workforce that can improve healthcare outcomes, building services around the needs of patients and communities. HEE will lead the new system to support healthcare providers and professionals as they identify the critical workforce challenges and ensure services have the right people with the right skills and behaviours, where and when they are needed.’’ Tweet No related posts.

pages.title: HEE appoints its senior management team | Health Education England
pages.content: Health Education England, the organisation responsible for providing national leadership for the education and training system, has today announced the appointments made to its senior management team. The appointments are: Dr Nicki Latham – Chief Operating Officer within the Directorate of Performance and Development Steve Clarke – Director of Finance Jo Lenaghan – Director of Strategy and Planning Lee Whitehead – Director of People and Communications Chris Welsh OBE – Director of Education and Quality Health Education England’s central role will be to ensure that the shape and skills of the future health and public health workforce evolves to sustain high quality outcomes for patients in the face of demographic and technological change. The organisation will allocate £5 billion multi-professional education and training budget funding to sixteen Local Education and Training Boards and hold them to account for delivery against national education outcomes, goals and priorities. Today’s appointments complete the first stage of recruitment for Health Education England. In the next phase, a Director of Nursing and a Medical Director will be appointed to be part of the Directorate of Education and Quality. Ian Cumming, Chief Executive of Health Education England said: “Health Education England exists for one reason alone which is to ensure that the highest possible quality of care is provided to patients. To deliver on this, we need to ensure that healthcare staff are not only recruited in the right numbers, but also with the right set of values and governance. “I am pleased that we have been able to secure such strong leaders to help realise this vision. The appointments should put us in a position to quickly start building a robust and valued education and training system that will develop and motivate our workforce and ensure the best outcomes for patients.” Dr Nicki Latham is currently Director of Operations and Partnerships at Health Education England, where she is leading the authorisation and development of the Local Education and Training Boards. Nicki was previously Chief Operating Officer for Information Systems at the National Institute for Health Research. Prior to this, Nicki worked for fifteen years in the higher education sector. Steve Clarke is Director of Finance at NHS Midlands and East. In this post he has also managed the Budget Bundle of £6bn on behalf of the Cluster Chief Executives and ensured that financial targets were met across three SHAs, with turnover approaching £30bn. Jo Lenaghan is Director of Policy for the National Quality Team. Previously she was Director of Reform at West Midlands SHA. Jo worked as Chief Adviser to Sir David Nicholson for four years and prior to this she was a Director of PPI and Communications at Birmingham and Black Country SHA. Lee Whitehead is Director of Communications and Engagement for NHS Midlands and East SHA Cluster and prior to that he was Director of Communications for NHS East of England. Before joining the SHA, Lee was a Board Director at large corporate communications agency, Fishburn Hedges, where he worked for companies and organisations across the public, private and voluntary sectors. Chris Welsh OBE is currently Medical Director at NHS Midlands and East, and was previously Medical Director at NHS Yorkshire and the Humber. Chris spent thirteen years as a consultant vascular surgeon and has been both an Undergraduate and Postgraduate Dean in the former Trent region. Sir Keith Pearson, Chairman of Health Education England said: “It’s good news that we now have a full team of highly respected executive directors to work alongside Ian Cumming. The individuals we have appointed bring a wealth of experience and expertise from a wide range of backgrounds. They all have a track record of success and I’m confident they will make a strong and immediate impact in their new roles.” For media enquiries please contact the Health Education England press office on 0113 254 5806. Tweet No related posts.

pages.title: Three Non-Executive Directors appointed | Health Education England
pages.content: Shirley Pearce, Kate Nealon and Ann Abraham have today been confirmed as Non Executive Directors of Health Education England. They will join Health Education England, the organisation that will provide national leadership to the new system of education and training in healthcare. This new system will give employers greater responsibility and accountability for planning and developing the workforce, within a national framework that is professionally informed and underpinned by strong academic links. Sir Keith Pearson, Chair of Health Education England, said: “It is essential that the Board of Health Education England has strong non-executive input into the discussions and decisions, which enable the organisation to discharge its responsibilities. Individually and collectively, Shirley, Kate and Ann bring a wealth of public and private sector experience which will ensure Health Education England achieves its key aim of enabling the delivery of high quality care to England’s population.” Shirley Pearce Shirley Pearce is a clinical psychologist by profession, was Vice Chancellor at Loughborough University for seven years and the Deputy Chair Commissioner for the Healthcare Commission. She currently sits on the Higher Education Funding Council for England and is a member of the Department’s expert panel carrying out a review of cosmetic surgery and procedures. Shirley has extensive experience at both executive and non-executive levels and has a strong educational and health background. Kate Nealon Kate Nealon is currently a Non-Executive Director with Argo Group International Holdings Ltd and formerly at Cable and Wireless, HBOS and Shire. She was the Head of Legal and Compliance at Standard Chartered Bank for many years. She has considerable business experience with strengths in risk management and corporate governance including a role at the Judge Business School at Cambridge University. She has held non-executive positions in both the UK and the US in publicly traded companies, charities and positions in the public sector. Ann Abraham Until January 2012, Ann Abraham was the UK Parliamentary Ombudsman and Health Service Ombudsman for England. In this role, she was always a staunch advocate for patient-centred, compassionate care. Ann has a breadth of experience as a Board Member in executive and non-executive roles and has a strong understanding of the issues and challenges facing HEE. ENDS Notes to editors For media enquiries please ring the Department of Health press office on 0207 210 5081 This appointment is made in accordance with the Code of Practice for Ministerial Appointments to Public Bodies, issued by the Commissioner for Public Appointments. All appointments are made on merit and political activity played no part in the selection process. However, in accordance with the original Nolan recommendations, there is a requirement for appointees’ political activity (if any declared) to be made public. Shirley Pearce, Kate Nealon and Ann Abraham have declared no political activity. For further information on the process for managing public appointments visit the Office of the Commissioner for Public Appointments website. Shirley Pearce is currently a Board Member of the Higher Education Funding Council for England. Kate Nealon and Ann Abraham do not hold any other public appointments. In due course, the Government plan to consolidate HEE by establishing it in primary legislation as a Non Departmental Public Body (NDPB). The Government intends to publish draft clauses for pre-legislative scrutiny in the second Parliamentary session. They will each receive £7,883 per annum for a time commitment of 2 to 3 days a month. For further information on i) Health Education England, navigate through this website, and ii) Liberating the NHS: Developing the Healthcare Workforce – From Design to Delivery visit the DH website . Tweet No related posts.

pages.title: BTBC steps forward | Health Education England
pages.content: After being part of the Better Training Better Care (BTBC) programme for the last 9 months, I thought it was about time I shared a few recent thoughts and experiences online – so welcome to my first attempt! The introduction of the BTBC programme was a huge step forward in medical education and training and we haven’t looked back. Our world is changing, expectations are changing, and we know we need to deliver services more effectively, which is why I am on a high after my last week – I can see the effect BTBC is starting to have on patient care. After a rainy few days in Manchester, I saw first-hand the impact our pilot projects are having. I was really impressed by the enthusiasm at Pennine Trust. Their gaming pilot in Oldham A&E has trainees busy doing more work-based placed assessments. It’s still early days there but trainees seem to be seeing more patients as part of the pilot changes as well as having more supervised training. South Manchester has initiated ‘Better Training, Better Care’ operating lists, ring-fencing surgery times for specialty trainees in years one and two, and last week implemented their first session. I spoke to the surgeon and the trainee who took part, and the trainee was delighted to have been given this opportunity. A meeting with Geoff Glover from the Higher Education Academy resulted in an exciting opportunity to do a joint piece of work showcasing technology that supports education and training – in particular, driving Temple’s recommendation of ‘making every moment count’. Back in Manchester, and again, raining, the BTBC Northern Relationship Manager, Emma, and I met with Sally Chisholm, Chief Executive of NHS Technology Centre. It was a great meeting and we received many contacts from the technology world that are bringing out new ideas. We’re now exploring whether any of these ideas can be used to improve education and training. I really enjoy these meetings – it’s always nice to be able to sit down, share ideas and kick around new thinking about the programme. Still in Machester (yes, I got my money’s worth out of the train ticket), I met with the wider management team of the North West Deanery. It was good to get feedback from those working hard to make Temple and Collins work on the ground. I was also pleased to hear enthusiasm for the development of community-faced places for foundation trainees, although everyone recognised that it will be hard to bring about this change. I know this is getting a little lengthy now, but there is so much going on that I want to share, so I’ll try and be brief! Our BTBC team officially moved across into Health Education England (HEE), and we met with HEE’s new Director of Nursing, Lisa Bayliss-Pratt (@hee_lisaBP). We’re both excited that nurses want to be part of the programme and make some of these changes happen. Lisa will be visiting some of the pilots over the coming months. The Academy of Medical Royal Colleges Training Advisory Group Committee is excited about the programme and have offered their suggestions about how progress might be made. I’ll also be chatting with Medical Directors and Clinical Directors over the coming weeks – it’ll be interested to hear their thoughts on how we can progress Lastly, I end this blog where it started – in Manchester (no doubt more rain!). I’ve been asked to speak at quite a few conferences over the coming months and am looking forward to the Faculty of Medical Leadership and Management conference on Wednesday – some sun please Manchester this time. So it’s been a jam packed few weeks which I hope will continue. It’s so good to see the programme develop and move forward. BTBC now has legs and we’re running! Until next time, Patrick Mitchell Director of National Programmes – Medical Education Tweet No related posts.

pages.title: Testing out technology | Health Education England
pages.content: I happened to be in Manchester again last week – and the sun was shining this time! I was at the Faculty of Medical Leadership and Management conference running two workshops with the team. We had great feedback around the barriers to making Temple a success, and there were ideas generated around engaging trainees and medical leaders in what needed to be done including rota redesign, consultant team job planning and seeking active board engagement – including having a Non Executive Director that has Medical Education as part of their portfolio of interest. The trainees gave good ideas about what community-facing placement might look like and made an interesting point about gaining experience in community settings without having to come out of acute focussed posts in a hospital. I met Dr Shelly Hennessey, an acute physician at Leighton Hospital in Mid Cheshire on Thursday – it’s amazing to see what one individual can do with enthusiasm and the support from the team. I saw the technology they’re working with, showing how trainees risk assess their patients and work through task lists prior to each handover. Though the software may not be compatible in all other Trusts the way in which the project is set up and structured, I am sure can be adopted elsewhere. I was late to Airedale (having to follow a bus down a country road for nearly an hour – well it felt that long), but did get to see the fantastic work Dr Richard Pope and Ian Williams are doing. I was able to sit in a telemedicine hub and see for myself how trainee-led outreach clinics can be networked back into the hospital for a consultant to give supervision, advice and handover. I also experienced how consultants at home can oversee the medical handover out of hours, providing appropriate supervision to trainees and making every moment count. This provides opportunity to assess trainee communication skills, organisation and delivery and assess their level of competence. We already have many ideas about how this might be expanded further under the BTBC programme. Friday saw me speaking at the North West Deanery’s first annual conference at the Bolton Wanderers Stadium. We had some interesting conversations about how many of the more experienced doctors believe Y-generation doctors in training need to be reminded of the importance of customer care and communication. It seems an issue that needs to be looked at, as I understand it’s not a popular part of the curricula and assessment, although I am interested to hear other’s thoughts about this – from all generations! Please email your thoughts to btbc@dh.gsi.gov.uk or tweet us at @BTBC_HEEnhs. I ended the week at the British Medical Journal’s Careers Fair on Friday afternoon. It was great to speak to so many trainees there with aspirations to go into a variety of specialties. I also had some important conversations regarding the general move of some hospital services into community based settings and how this may affect career choice. This week I’m back in the office (no more Manchester for a while as much as it’s always great to go there!) and look forward to catching up with the BTBC team to find out how each of the workstreams are progressing. Until next time, Patrick Mitchell Director of National Programmes – Medical Education Tweet No related posts.

pages.title: Medical Director appointed | Health Education England
pages.content: Health Education England (HEE), the new national organisation with leadership responsibility for the education, training and development of the health and healthcare workforce in England, has appointed Professor Wendy Reid as its Medical Director. Professor Reid is currently the Dean of Postgraduate Medicine at London Deanery. She is a Consultant Gynaecologist and has been an Associate Dean and Postgraduate Dean in London since 2001, leading on Anaesthetics and Paediatric training and sector development across North Central and North East London. In September 2010, Wendy was elected Vice President of the Royal College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists with responsibility for education, a role which provided the opportunity to influence education and training policy nationally. In her new role, Professor Reid will provide leadership and oversight of undergraduate and postgraduate medical education, working in partnership with a range of stakeholders to ensure it is of the highest quality. Professor Reid will contribute to the strategic direction, long term development, priority setting and agreed priorities of HEE and attend its Board meetings. HEE’s Director of Education and Quality, Dr Chris Welsh, welcomed the appointment, saying: ‘Wendy will be a great asset to HEE, given her knowledge and understanding about education and training, particularly the local challenges. She brings particular knowledge of clinical leadership and higher education, with a focus on patient safety, high quality care and multi-professional working. She has an outstanding reputation in leading improvements and will be a huge support to myself and all who will drive forward HEE’s priorities.’ Professor Reid said: ‘I am delighted to be joining Health Education England as Medical Director. I am particularly pleased to be part of an organisation that will lead the way in developing the future workforce to raise the quality of care for patients.’ For media enquiries please contact the Health Education England press office on 0113 254 5806. ENDS Notes to editors HEE is the NHS engine that will deliver a better health and healthcare workforce for England . The organisation is responsible for the education, training, and personal development of every member of staff, and recruiting for values from schools and into our Universities. HEE is employer-led, to provide the right workforce, with the right skills and values, in the right place at the right time, to better meet the needs and wants of patients. HEE’s mission is to improve health outcomes for the people of England by developing people for health and healthcare. Health Education England was formally established as a Special Health Authority on 28 June 2012 . Professor Reid has academic interests in assessment and standard setting and was the Obstetrician and Gynaecologist representative on the General Medical Council PLAB examination for several years. She has extensive experience in postgraduate examinations and introduced new techniques to the Member Royal College of Gynaecologists (MRCG) examination. She chaired the Royal College of Gynaecology (RCOG) working party on Advanced Training which uniquely introduced innovative training modules linked to workforce planning within training programmes. She was the first chair of the Curriculum Committee at the RCOG and was jointly responsible for the new curriculum launched in 2007. Tweet No related posts.

pages.title: Our Strategic Intent | Health Education England
pages.content: Health Education England (HEE) is officially established on the 1st April 2013, and we are seeking your views on our proposed strategic priorities. ‘Introducing Health Education England: Our Strategic Intent’ sets out our purpose and the role that we will play in leading education, training and development across the system to deliver improvements in the quality of care for patients. It also includes high level guidance for workforce planners. This document is informed by discussions by our Board and with the Chairs and Managing Directors of 13 Local Education and Training Boards (LETB). We are publishing it to obtain your views, and those of our stakeholders, to help shape our vision and support its implementation. The aim of the publication is two-fold. Firstly, it clearly sets out the purpose of HEE and our LETBs: that we exist to support the delivery of excellent healthcare and health improvement to the patients and public of England. We do this by ensuring that we have the right numbers of staff, with the right skills and right behaviours, when and wherever they are needed. Because of the time it takes to select, educate, train, recruit and develop the healthcare workforce, the decisions we make today will need to be informed by our imperfect understanding of the future. This purpose, and our focus on the current and future workforce, will be at the heart of all that we do, and we will use it as a guide to action over the coming months and years. Secondly, we realise that we cannot achieve our purpose alone. We will need to work with many stakeholders to understand their current challenges and future opportunities, so that HEE, through our LETBs, can make local and national visions happen through our education commissions and ongoing training and development programmes. From today, we are asking our stakeholders to join a conversation with us to help further define our strategic priorities. The Strategic Intent was formally presented at the Board meeting on 5th February 2013 . We would genuinely welcome your views on our proposed priorities and our Strategic Intent document, by emailing HEE.StrategicIntentFeedback@nhs.net by 31st March 2013. In the meantime, we would like to encourage you to help us share Building HEE: Our Strategic Intent, through your networks, at conferences and speaking engagements or via social media. We look forward to listening to and working with you over the coming months on our core purpose of delivering a better health and healthcare workforce for England. Tweet No related posts.

pages.title: Statement on Francis Inquiry | Health Education England
pages.content: The report released today by Robert Francis QC is shaming for the NHS. The failure in the systems that were supposed to oversee and regulate our hospitals are laid bare for all to see and it is important that the NHS takes these issues seriously and works together to make sure we make the changes needed. However, perhaps even more worrying is the focus on the basic lack of care and compassion by individual nurses and doctors and other staff who worked in a poisonous climate in Mid Staffordshire, a culture that has no place in any caring environment and definitely not in our NHS. Without this culture, which Robert Francis describes as “insidious and negative” there would have been no need for two Francis inquiries and there would have not been the deaths and harm to patients at Mid Staffordshire NHS Foundation Trust that led us to where we are today. That is why Health Education England (HEE) will be at the forefront of dealing with the problems of values, culture and behaviours that are at the root of the issues addressed by Robert Francis today. Professor Ian Cumming, Chief Executive of HEE, said: “The values of the NHS, of public service, of compassion and of care are at the root of why the people of this country love the NHS and also why most people who work in the NHS join it in the first place. It is clear that at Mid Staffordshire something went badly wrong with the culture over many years and the values that should be core to everyone who looks after patients were missing or eroded over time. “Even though the scale of what happened at Mid Staffordshire makes it stand out, there are still pockets of poor culture, poor behaviour, lack of care and lack of compassion around the rest of the NHS. “This has to change and change now. If we get the culture right and ensure that the NHS values run through all that our staff do, we will do more to protect patients than all the regulators and systems in the world. “ HEE needs time to read the report in full and consider all of its 290 recommendations, but I also want to be clear about our responsibilities as the new people development service for health and healthcare in England. In response to the Francis report, HEE will lead a cross-NHS set of programmes to ensure we recruit for values at all levels of the NHS from the consultant and chief executive to nurse, porter and receptionist. We will develop a process for NHS employers to use to test values and behaviours of potential employees. If people can’t demonstrate the right values and behaviours they should not get jobs in our NHS. It is as simple as that. “My personal belief is that we should recruit for values, train around values and appraise individuals based on expression of values. There should be no place in the NHS for people who don’t subscribe to the core values as set out in the NHS Constitution. “HEE will be talking to Universities to ensure that every student we directly or indirectly fund to study nursing, medicine, physiotherapy or any other health related course should be interviewed prior to being offered a place and they should also be subject to an assessment of their values and behaviours. If potential students cannot demonstrate the right values and behaviours to work in healthcare, why should tax payers spend tens or hundreds of thousands of pounds paying for the course for that individual? “ We will also be looking at the content of training programmes for all staff – particularly focussing on the large number of support staff – ensuring that in addition to values and behaviours people also have the appropriate levels of skills and training to undertake their roles ” . For more information, contact Helen Jackson on 0121 695 2252. Tweet No related posts.

pages.title: Health Education England » HEE pledge on infection control training to improve patient care
pages.content: 11 March 2013 - 11:01 Health Education England (HEE) has made a commitment to ensure that infection control is part of all of its funded courses to ensure improved quality of care for patients. The pledge follows publication of a report on antimicrobial resistance and infectious diseases from England ’s Chief Medical Officer ( CMO ), Professor Dame Sally Davies. The second volume of the CMO ’s annual report calls for the development of new antibiotics to treat diseases that evolve and become resistant to existing drugs, as well as looking after the antibiotics we already have, which means better hygiene measures to prevent infections, prescribing fewer antibiotics and making sure they are only prescribed when needed. The report also states that more action is needed to tackle the next generation of healthcare associated infections, including new strains that will be harder to treat. The report states that the greatest potential for reducing the impact of infectious diseases includes the education and continuing professional development of health, public health and care professionals as a key component. There is good evidence of the effectiveness of improving staff knowledge and understanding of infection control in improving health outcomes. The CMO ’s report has been welcomed by HEE’s Director of Education and Quality Professor Chris Welsh. Professor Welsh said: ‘HEE strongly support this report. Infection control, particularly control of healthcare associated infections, is essential to the delivery of quality care for patients and the public. He said: ‘We fully support the responsible use of antibiotics; NHS staff must have the skills, knowledge and training to prescribe and administer antibiotics appropriately.’ ‘HEE is working for patients and we put patients first in everything we do to improve health and wellbeing. We commit to ensuring that infection control is part of all the courses we fund.’ For further information contact Richard Green, Head of Media Relations, 0208 433 6845 / 07557 204428 Notes for editors: HEE was established on 28 June 2012, working as a shadow Special Health Authority from 1 October 2012. It will take on its full operational responsibilities from1 April 2013. It will have five national functions: providing national leadership on planning and developing the healthcare and public health workforce; promoting high quality education and training that is responsive to the changing needs of patients and local communities, including responsibility for ensuring the effective delivery of important national functions such as medical trainee recruitment; ensuring security of supply of the health and public health workforce; appointing and supporting the development of LETBs; and allocating and accounting for NHS education and training resources and the outcomes achieved. For more information on HEE visit our website – www.hee.nhs.uk or follow us on Twitter- @nhs_healthedeng or Facebook- www.facebook.com/nhshee Tweet Categories: Home • News

pages.title: HEE recommends authorisation of 13 Local Education and Training Boards | Health Education England
pages.content: Health Education England (HEE) has recommended the establishment of 13 Local Education and Training Boards (LETBs), which will take on their functions from 1 April if approved. LETB boards, which will be committees of HEE, are made up of representatives from local providers of NHS services. Final decisions about the authorisation of LETBs will be taken at the HEE board meeting on 27 March. Each of the proposed 13 LETBs has a number of areas for development. Areas for development, or conditions, are not indicators of the ability of LETBs, which each have their own unique circumstances. Up until now, LETBs have been operating in shadow form with delegated authority from Strategic Health Authorities. Since November last year, they have been going through a rigorous authorisation process to test their abilities in six specific areas: vision and leadership; meaningful engagement with key partners; good governance; effective financial control; organisational capacity; and outcome-led improvements. At their meeting on 27 March, the HEE board will need to decide whether the LETBs have reached the standards required in each of these areas and are ready to lead local health care education and training. Board members will decide whether each LETB should be authorised, authorised with conditions, or not authorised. Recommendations and any relevant conditions will be available here http://hee.nhs.uk/category/heeboardpapers/ Dr Nicki Latham, HEE Chief Operating Officer, said: ‘With employers and professionals as part of their governing bodies, LETBs will improve the quality of education and training outcomes to meet the needs of patients, the public and service providers in their areas. Dr Latham said: ‘They will have the flexibility to invest in education and training to support innovation and development of the wider health system. They will also be able to ensure that money in the new system follows students and trainees on the basis of quality and education and training outcomes. LETBs will be key in ensuring that the system responds to the recommendations of the Francis report and help improve the quality of patient care at every turn.’ From 1 April, HEE will have a dedicated education and training budget of around £5 billion and the majority of this will be spent locally by LETBs. Dr Latham said: ‘HEE exists for one reason and one reason only: to support the delivery of excellent healthcare and health improvement to the patients and the public of England, by ensuring that or workforce has the right numbers, skills, values and behaviours, at the right time and in the right place. HEE and its LETBs will be spending £10,000 a minute to ensure high quality education and training that improves care for patients.’ For further information contact Richard Green, Head of Media Relations, 0208 433 6845/07557 204428 Notes for editors: HEE was established on 28 June 2012 , working as a shadow Special Health Authority from 1 October 2012 . It will take on its full operational responsibilities from1 April 2013. It will have five national functions: providing national leadership on planning and developing the healthcare and public health workforce; promoting high quality education and training that is responsive to the changing needs of patients and local communities, including responsibility for ensuring the effective delivery of important national functions such as medical trainee recruitment; ensuring security of supply of the health and public health workforce; appointing and supporting the development of LETBs; and allocating and accounting for NHS education and training resources and the outcomes achieved. For more information on HEE visit our website – www.hee.nhs.uk or follow us on Twitter- @nhs_healthedeng or Facebook- www.facebook.com/nhshee Health Education England supports the missions and values of the NHS Constitution LETB Recommended status of authorisation East Midlands Authorised with areas for development East of England Authorised with areas for development Yorkshire and the Humber Authorised with areas for development and one condition Wessex Authorised with areas for development and one condition Thames Valley Authorised with areas for development and conditions North West London Authorised with areas for development and one condition South London Authorised with areas for development and conditions North Central and East London Authorised with areas for development and one condition Kent, Surrey and Sussex Authorised with areas for development and conditions North East Authorised with areas for development and conditions North West Authorised with areas for development and conditions West Midlands Authorised with areas for development South West Authorised with areas for development Tweet

pages.title: Health Education England » Health Education England to pilot healthcare experience for aspirant nurses before university
pages.content: 26 March 2013 - 13:53 Today Health Education England is welcoming the announcement by Secretary of State for Health Jeremy Hunt MP that HEE should pilot a scheme whereby those who wish to study NHS funded nursing degrees should first spend time working as a healthcare assistant to assess their values and behaviours and to help them ensure they are making the right career choice. In his response to the second Francis Inquiry into the failings at the Mid Staffordshire NHS Foundation Trust, the Secretary of State said: ‘Starting with pilots, every student who seeks NHS funding for nursing degrees should first serve up to a year as a healthcare assistant, to promote frontline caring experience and values, as well as academic strength. They will also provide students with helpful experience for managing healthcare assistants when they qualify and enter practice…HEE will explore whether there is merit in extending this principle to other NHS trainees.’ Professor Ian Cumming OBE, Chief Executive of HEE, said: Health Education England exists to improve the quality of care delivered to patients by focusing on the education, training and development of current and future healthcare staff. We therefore welcome the Secretary of State highlighting the importance of values and behaviours to ensure we have an NHS we can all continue to be proud of. Failing to abide by NHS values and the culture that developed in Mid Staffs led to the sort of behaviours that have no place in our NHS. Professor Cumming said: ‘In the future, by asking prospective students across a range of courses HEE funds to undertake up to a year of real work as a Healthcare Assistant we can start to ensure that the NHS recruits not just for skills and academic ability but also for values and behaviours that can be tested in a real healthcare environment before the NHS spends tens of thousands of pounds on their education. He said: ‘HEE is committed to working with partners to pilot this idea across NHS and Higher Education organisations we work with, to learn what works best and then agree with patients, students, universities and colleagues across the healthcare system how we move forward to spread best practice.’ Partners are already showing their support for being involved in the pilots and working together to make this initiative a success. Katherine Fenton OBE, Director of Nursing, University College London Hospital, said: ‘I fully support this proposal and believe it will provide invaluable insight for students as they embark on their healthcare career. Engaging with patients at the very start of their career will help students underpin their training with a first hand understanding of patient needs.” Dr Chris Fowler, Managing Director of Health Education North Central and East London, added: ‘These internships will provide new recruits to healthcare with a fantastic opportunity to obtain first hand knowledge of the NHS. Experiencing healthcare in action allows students to demonstrate the values and behaviours the NHS needs, whilst enhancing the ability of the NHS to recruit the right people to work with and for patients. With our NHS and university partners we are delighted to have the opportunity to develop and further evaluate this exciting proposal.’ Professor Linda Lang, Dean of Health and Wellbeing, University of Wolverhampton, said: ‘We are interested in supporting the concept of applicants to nursing and AHP courses undertaking a year of work as a healthcare assistant before progressing to their professional studies. This philosophy fits with our commitment to ensure applicants make fully informed decisions about their career direction in health profession. We currently work closely with partners in practice to ensure applicants to nursing and other health professions demonstrate that they understand the range of career opportunities offered by the NHS and that they demonstrate the right values and attitudes, before they are offered a place to study. We welcome an opportunity to explore and evaluate ways of enhancing the recruitment of the right people with the right attitudes for the future delivery of healthcare.’ Cheryl Etches, Chief Nurse, The Royal Wolverhampton Hospitals NHS Trust, added: ‘Healthcare work is challenging at its best whilst also being extremely rewarding. Many people commence training for a healthcare profession only to find the reality of their clinical placements a shock and sometimes, sadly, decide healthcare isn’t the right choice for them. Potential healthcare workers of the future could benefit from exposure to the real healthcare environment before committing to a healthcare career and its associated training.’ Professor David Sines CBE PhD, Pro Vice Chancellor, Buckinghamshire New University, said: ‘We would be most interested in participating in an exploratory pilot project to consider how best to provide pre-qualifying healthcare students with pre-entry experience in healthcare settings as proposed within the context of the Francis Report.’ For further information contact Richard Green, Head of Media Relations, 0208 433 6845/07557 204428 Notes for editors: HEE is committed to ensuring that we play our full part in ensuring that the lessons learnt from Mid Staffs ring through the system, so, as well as piloting pre-degree work as a healthcare assistant programme we are also working to introduce a new test for behaviours and values before the NHS recruits into both universities and our hospitals and other initiatives. For further information please see our Strategic Intent Document, which is available here: http://hee.nhs.uk/2013/01/31/our-strategic-intent/ HEE was established on 28 June 2012, working as a shadow Special Health Authority from 1 October 2012. It will take on its full operational responsibilities from1 April 2013. It will have five national functions: providing national leadership on planning and developing the healthcare and public health workforce; promoting high quality education and training that is responsive to the changing needs of patients and local communities, including responsibility for ensuring the effective delivery of important national functions such as medical trainee recruitment; ensuring security of supply of the health and public health workforce; appointing and supporting the development of LETBs; and allocating and accounting for NHS education and training resources and the outcomes achieved. For more information on HEE visit our website – www.hee.nhs.uk or follow us on Twitter- @nhs_healthedeng or Facebook- www.facebook.com/nhshee Health Education England supports the missions and values of the NHS Constitution Tweet Categories: Home • News

pages.title: Health Education England » HEE approves authorisation of 13 Local Education and Training Boards
pages.content: 27 March 2013 - 15:06 Health Education England (HEE) has approved the establishment of 13 Local Education and Training Boards (LETBs), which will take on their functions from 1 April. LETB boards, which will be committees of HEE, are made up of representatives from local providers of NHS services and cover the whole of England. They are: Health Education East Midlands Health Education East of England Health Education Yorkshire and the Humber Health Education Wessex Health Education Thames Valley Health Education North West London Health Education South London Health Education North Central and East London Health Education Kent, Surrey and Sussex Health Education North East Health Education North West Health Education West Midlands Health Education South West At a HEE Board meeting today, all 13 were authorised after undergoing a rigorous assessment process to assess their abilities in areas including meaningful engagement with key partners and outcome-led improvements and they will now lead local healthcare education and training. Dr Nicki Latham, HEE Chief Operating Officer, said: ‘Health Education England exists to improve the quality of care delivered to patients by focusing on the education, training and development of current and future healthcare staff. With employers and professionals as part of their governing bodies, LETBs will improve the quality of education and training outcomes to meet the needs of patients, the public and service providers in their areas.’ Dr Latham said: ‘They will have the flexibility to invest in education and training to support innovation and development of the wider health system. They will also be able to ensure that money in the new system follows students and trainees on the basis of quality and education and training outcomes. LETBs will be key in ensuring that the system responds to the recommendations of the Francis report and helping to improve the quality of care at every turn.’ She said: ‘A tremendous amount of work has gone into this process and the LETBs are to be commended in what they have achieved in a short period of time.’ For further information contact Richard Green, Head of Media Relations, 0208 433 6845/07557 204428 Notes for editors: HEE was established on 28 June 2012, working as a shadow Special Health Authority from 1 October 2012. It will take on its full operational responsibilities from1 April 2013. It will have five national functions: providing national leadership on planning and developing the healthcare and public health workforce; promoting high quality education and training that is responsive to the changing needs of patients and local communities, including responsibility for ensuring the effective delivery of important national functions such as medical trainee recruitment; ensuring security of supply of the health and public health workforce; appointing and supporting the development of LETBs; and allocating and accounting for NHS education and training resources and the outcomes achieved. For more information on HEE visit our website – www.hee.nhs.uk or follow us on Twitter- @nhs_healthedeng or Facebook- www.facebook.com/nhshee Health Education England supports the missions and values of the NHS Constitution Tweet Categories: Home • News

pages.title: Health Education England » Shadowing for Foundation Year 1 (F1) Doctors
pages.content: 8 April 2013 - 16:06 Shadowing for F1 doctors is set to continue in 2013 following the success of the project in 2012. The first few weeks of employment for medical graduates are not only stressful but are also associated with increased risk for patients and employing organisations. In 2012, HEE introduced a period of paid shadowing immediately before medical graduates took up their F1 post. Evidence suggested that shadowing can reduce the number of serious adverse events. The project’s aim is to ensure that all appointees to F1 spend a minimum of four working days shadowing the F1 job that they will be taking up and completing a trust-based induction. This will help them to become familiar with their new working environment and include a handover of their clinical responsibilities. Chris Welsh, Director of Education and Quality, has written to all medical students and NHS chief executives to advise them of the new arrangements. Chris said: “This shadowing period will equip our new colleagues with the local knowledge and skills needed to provide safe, high quality patient care, from their first day as a F1 doctor. It builds on a range of developments in undergraduate medical education including student assistantships.” “While I acknowledge that foundation trusts cannot be required to implement shadowing, almost all supported this in 2012. I hope that they recognise the benefits to patients and newly appointed F1 doctors of shadowing.” The latest start date for shadowing this year should be Thursday 1 August 2013. Guidance for 2013 and details of good practice can be seen here: Shadowing Guidance 2013 Tweet Categories: Home • News

pages.title: Health Education England » Statement from Lisa Bayliss-Pratt, Director of Nursing
pages.content: 22 April 2013 - 11:57 We are disappointed that the RCN chose to use the word ‘stupid’ about one of the Francis Report recommendations to support better care in the NHS. Francis recommendation 187 said: ‘There should be a national entry-level requirement that student nurses spend a minimum period of time, at least three months, working on the direct care of patients under the supervision of a registered nurse. Such experience should include direct care of patients, ideally including the elderly, and involve hands-on physical care. Satisfactory completion of this direct care experience should be a pre-condition to continuation in nurse training.’ HEE welcomes this recommendation. By asking prospective students to undertake up to a year of real work as healthcare assistants we can start to ensure that the NHS recruits not just for skills and academic ability but also for values and behaviours that can be tested in a real healthcare environment before the NHS spends tens of thousands of pounds on their education. Up to a quarter of nursing students drop out during their degree, often after their first taste of real hands-on care. We want to work with a variety of groups and individuals from nursing and higher education to test the most effective timescale for the pilots, from at least three months as in the Francis Report and up to a year as in the Government response to that report, potentially with participants having placements working as healthcare assistants in a hospital, in a community setting and in a third setting of their choice. HEE are in contact with the RCN about them being part of the steering group that will oversee the pilots, helping to ensure that we monitor, evaluate and learn lessons. For further information contact Richard Green, Head of Media Relations, 07557 204428 For more information on HEE visit our website – www.hee.nhs.uk or follow us on Twitter- @nhs_healthedeng or Facebook- www.facebook.com/nhshee Health Education England supports the missions and values of the NHS Constitution Tweet Categories: Home • News

pages.title: Health Education England » Top nurses to oversee pilots on pre-degree care experience
pages.content: 9 May 2013 - 12:21 England’s top nurses will oversee a pilot scheme for student nurses to spend time working as a healthcare assistant before taking up their degree. They are part of a national steering group announced today by Health Education England. The group will be chaired by Sir Stephen Moss, a non-executive director at Derby Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust and former turnaround chair at the Mid Staffordshire NHS Foundation Trust. The group includes nursing leaders from the Royal College of Nursing, the Nursing and Midwifery Council, the Care Quality Commission, NHS England, the Department of Health, Public Health England, NHS Employers and the NHS Trust Development Authority. Robert Francis, in his inquiry report into the failings at Mid Staffs, recommended that student nurses should spend at least three months working on the direct care of patients before their degree course. He called for an increased focus in nurse training and education on the practical requirements of delivering compassionate care and evidence of the appropriate values, attitudes and behaviours. The Government response to the Francis report proposed that student nurses should spend up to a year working on the front line in order to receive NHS funding for their degree.The steering group announced today will oversee a pilot programme, working with partners across the NHS and higher education, to see how best to take forward these proposals and assess the most appropriate timescale. Pilots are likely to involve up to 200 nursing students on paid placements across the country from this autumn and the steering group will also be responsible for evaluation in areas including the ability to test for values and behaviours and reductions in attrition rates. Professor Ian Cumming OBE, Chief Executive of Health Education England, said: ‘By asking prospective students to undertake up to a year of experience on the front line, we can start to ensure that the NHS recruits not just for skills and academic ability but also for values and behaviours that can be tested in a healthcare environment before the NHS spends thousands of pounds on their education. Professor Cumming said: ‘The healthcare experience will allow students to understand whether nursing and hands-on care is right for them. It will mean better, more experienced and more committed students in our universities. That is good for patients and good for the NHS. He said: ‘It should also help to reduce the drop-out rates at university. It should be hard to be a nurse – a vocation, a real desire, not just something you accept as second best so you can do a degree course.’ Sir Stephen Moss, Chair of the steering group, said: ‘I am delighted to have been asked to chair the steering group for this important piece of work and look forward very much to working with a very experienced and committed group of colleagues on the implementation and evaluation of the pilots. Sir Stephen said: ‘I am proud to be a nurse and want to do everything I can to ensure that we take this opportunity to address the many challenges currently facing our profession. He said: ‘It is vitally important that we deliver skilled patient care, with kindness and compassion, and piloting this pre-degree experience will enable us to test out the effectiveness of exposing potential students to front line care and professional values at an early stage, before their formal degree programme. Of one thing I am certain, that is that things cannot stay as they are. We owe it to those we serve to continually seek new and innovative ways to meet their needs.’ Ends For further information contact Richard Green, Head of Media Relations, 07557 204428 Notes for editors: HEE was established on 28 June 2012, working as a shadow Special Health Authority from 1 October 2012. It took on its full operational responsibilities from1 April 2013. It has five national functions: providing national leadership on planning and developing the healthcare and public health workforce; promoting high quality education and training that is responsive to the changing needs of patients and local communities, including responsibility for ensuring the effective delivery of important national functions such as medical trainee recruitment; ensuring security of supply of the health and public health workforce; appointing and supporting the development of LETBs; and allocating and accounting for NHS education and training resources and the outcomes achieved. A full list of the steering group membership is attached below, along with a biography for Sir Stephen Moss. For more information on HEE visit our website – www.hee.nhs.uk or follow us on Twitter- @nhs_healthedeng or Facebook- www.facebook.com/nhshee Health Education England supports the missions and values of the NHS Constitution Steering Group Sir Stephen Moss (Chair) Non-executive director, Derby Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust, Lisa Bayliss-Pratt (Vice-chair and project director) Director of Nursing, Health Education England Jo Lenaghan Director of Strategy, Health Education England Jane Cummings Chief Nursing Officer, NHS England Viv Bennett Director of Nursing, Department of Health and Public Health England Peter Blythin Director of Nursing, NHS Trust Development Authority Peter Carter Chief Executive and General Secretary, Royal College of Nursing Gail Adams Head of Nursing, UNISON Ieuan Ellis Chair, Council of Deans of Health Dame Christine Beasley Chair, North Central and East London, Local Education and Training Boards Dean Royles Chief Executive, NHS Employers Mark Newbold Chief Executive, Heart of England NHS Foundation Trust, CEO Provider Sally Brearley Chair, Nursing and Care Quality Forum Jackie Smith / Judith Ellis Nursing and Midwifery Council Ann Farenden Care Quality Commission Alan Robson Deputy Director of Workforce Development Strategy, Department of Health Biography – Sir Stephen Moss Stephen is a nurse by background, and has spent his entire career in the NHS. After a number of years in clinical practice, he moved into a variety of nursing and general management roles and has over 30 years experience in posts at board level, including chief nurse, chief executive, non executive director and chairman. Stephen was appointed by the Secretary of State as a Commissioner on the board of the first health service quality regulator, the Commission for Health Improvement (CHI). In February 2009, Stephen was asked to join the board of Mid Staffordshire NHS Foundation Trust as a non executive director, shortly before the publication of the highly critical Healthcare Commission Report. He took on the role of chairman in August 2009 until January 2012. Stephen has recently been appointed a non executive director at Derby Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust. Tweet Categories: Home • News

pages.title: Health Education England » Health Education England support for integrated care initiative
pages.content: 14 May 2013 - 11:00 For health, care and support to be ‘integrated’, it must be person-centred, coordinated, and tailored to the needs and preferences of the individual, their carer and family. It means moving away from episodic care to a more holistic approach to health, care and support needs, that puts the needs and experience of people at the centre of how services are organised and delivered. Where local areas have succeeded in integrating health, care and support services, too often it has been despite the national system rather than because of it. This is why Health Education England has joined a range of national partner organisations, to support local areas to tackle these national barriers and allow locally-led, integrated services to flourish. Context setting for the Framework document As national partners, we have co-produced Integrated Care and Support: our shared commitment – a framework document on integration. The document, signed by all the partners, sets out how local areas can use existing structures such as Health and Wellbeing Boards to bring together local authorities, the NHS, care and support providers, education, housing services, public health and others to make further steps towards integration. Context setting for the Narrative National Voices, a national coalition of health and care charities, has developed a person-centred ‘narrative’ on integration. This is an agreed definition of what we mean by ‘integrated’ care. It provides a guide to the sort of things that integrated care will achieve, such as better planning, more personal involvement of the person using services, and free access to good information. It also provides some clarity over what local areas should be aiming to achieve practically, in their efforts to integrate services. It is written not just for the experts, but for patients, people, families and carers. It shows them what they have a right to expect, so they can then demand the most helpful care and support. As a national partner we have adopted this definition of what good integrated care and support looks and feels like for people, and we are asking local areas to sign up to using it too. Context setting for the Pioneers programme Together the national partners are asking local areas to express an interest in becoming ‘pioneers’ to act as exemplars, demonstrating the use of ambitious and innovative approaches to efficiently deliver integrated care. We are looking for pioneers that will work across the whole of their local health, public health and care and support systems, and alongside other local authority departments as necessary, to achieve and demonstrate the scale of change that is required. The national partners will provide tailored support to pioneers. In return, we expect them to be at the forefront of sharing and promoting what they’ve learned for wider adoption across the country. To read the framework, Integrated Care and Support: our shared commitment , click here. Read the letter inviting local areas to become pioneers: click here. To read the National Voices, person-centred ‘narrative’ on integration click here. For an easy read version of the narrative click here . Tweet Categories: Home • News

pages.title: Health Education England » New national dementia training launched for healthcare staff
pages.content: 15 May 2013 - 10:19 A new online training resource has been launched today to ensure that all staff in the NHS and in social care can be dementia-aware. The e-learning resource will help to deliver the roll out of the Prime Minister’s dementia package that would see 100,000 nurses and health care assistants receiving dementia training by e-learning by 2015. The e-learning sessions in dementia have been developed by e-Learning for Healthcare, part of Health Education England (HEE), the new body responsible for the education and training of health and healthcare staff. Jeremy Hunt, Secretary of State for Health announced further measures to tackle dementia, one year on from the Prime Minister’s Challenge of Dementia. This ambitious programme of work is designed to make a real difference to the lives of people with dementia and their families and carers. The Dementia e-learning sessions have been designed to familiarise health and social care staff with recognising and understanding dementia and to be able to signpost appropriate support. Written by experts in both psychiatry and medicine for the elderly, the e-learning supports both the implementation of the National Dementia Strategy and David Cameron’s challenge. Staff will be able to access three 30 minute sessions of learning which will support staff with difficult questions such as ‘I am worried about Dad’ that could be asked of anyone in contact with patients and families on a day to day basis. It also covers the importance of public health messages and addressing social stigma as essential in making a difference in caring for people with dementia. In addition, a further ten 30 minute sessions are available which support more advanced practice in assessing and managing dementia, whilst equipping staff with the skills to provide high quality dementia care. Professor Chris Welsh, Director of Education and Quality of HEE said: “The nature of dementia means that managing the condition can pose unique and sometimes difficult issues for staff, both in the hospital and in the community. “We believe that care for patients with dementia needs to start in education to create a dementia-aware workforce. This e-learning tool is the first step in a three stage programme led by Health Education England in improving the care for those with dementia. “Over the coming months, we will be working with providers of education to ensure that dementia and other long term conditions play a far greater role in the knowledge and the skills we expect of those who graduate to become professionals in the NHS. “This will become a mandatory part of the education we expect all staff to have before joining the NHS”. Stage three will be the delivery of expert leaders in each NHS institution who will work across disciplines, and with senior staff, to lead dementia awareness, treatment and training programmes. The development of these posts will be supported by Local Education and Training Boards (LETBs) in their work locally with NHS providers of care. Ends For further information contact Richard Green, Head of Media Relations, 07557 204428 Notes for editors: HEE was established on 28 June 2012, working as a shadow Special Health Authority from 1 October 2012. It took on its full operational responsibilities from1 April 2013. It has five national functions: providing national leadership on planning and developing the healthcare and public health workforce; promoting high quality education and training that is responsive to the changing needs of patients and local communities, including responsibility for ensuring the effective delivery of important national functions such as medical trainee recruitment; ensuring security of supply of the health and public health workforce; appointing and supporting the development of LETBs; and allocating and accounting for NHS education and training resources and the outcomes achieved. The e-learning dementia resource can be accessed here http://www.elfh.org.uk/projects/dementia/ . e-Learning for Healthcare (e-LfH) is an award-winning programme providing national, quality assured online training content for the healthcare profession. Contributing to the revolution in healthcare training in the UK, e-LfH’s e-learning projects enhance traditional learning, support existing teaching methods and provide a valuable reference point which can be accessed anytime, anywhere. Health Education England supports the missions and values of the NHS Constitution. Tweet Categories: Home • News

pages.title: Health Education England » New education and training measures to improve patient care
pages.content: 28 May 2013 - 00:15 Professor Ian Cumming, Chief Executive of Health Education England, has today welcomed the Government’s Mandate to Health Education England that sets out plans for education and training for all NHS staff. The mandate to HEE, the new organisation set up to provide national leadership on education, training and workforce development, includes a comprehensive and wide-ranging series of measures. It is a blueprint for NHS staff training. It is the first time ever that a single organisation has had responsibility for all NHS staff education, recruitment, training and development. HEE has a budget of £5 billion to help NHS staff improve their ability to care for patients. HEE is central to the reformed health system and is uniquely placed to have the greatest impact on improvements in patient care by focusing on values and behaviours and educating, training and developing the workforce responsible for delivering that care. The plans announced today emphasise the importance of training for support staff providing community care and preventing patients, those with long term conditions for example, needing to go into hospital. The mandate includes a focus on: recruitment into all new NHS-funded training posts including assessment of appropriate values and behaviours; ensuring every student who seeks NHS funding for nursing degrees should first serve up to a year as a healthcare assistant; delivery of additional trained health visitors to increase the workforce by 4,200 full time equivalents by April 2015; providing dementia awareness training for all NHS staff who look after patients, ensuring that 100,000 staff have foundation level training by March 2014; and commissioning the required number of IAPT (increasing access to psychological therapies) training places. Professor Cumming said: ‘Health Education England exists for one reason and one reason only: to improve the quality of care delivered to patients by focusing on the education, training and development of the current and future workforce. He said: ‘We are here to develop people for health and healthcare. We are responsible for the education, training and personal development of every member of NHS staff and for recruiting for values from our schools and into our universities. ‘It costs £70,000 to train a qualified nurse and £500,000 to train a GP. Investing in our current and future workforce is the only way to future-proof the NHS, ensuring that our staff have the flexibility and skills to provide care in the community as we respond to the demands of older patients with more complex needs.’ The mandate published today is aligned with national NHS priorities to tackle preventable deaths; empower and support people living with long-term conditions; introduce a culture of caring; and for the diagnosis, treatment and care of people with dementia in England to be among the best in Europe. It is set out under six broad themes: support for service priorities; NHS values and behaviours; excellent education; competent and capable staff; working in partnership; and value for money. Read the mandate here: Delivering high quality, effective, compassionate care: Developing the right people with the right skills and the right values. A mandate from the Government to Health Education England: April 2013 to March 2015 For further information contact Richard Green, Head of Media Relations, 07557 204428 Health Education England supports the missions and values of the NHS Constitution Tweet Categories: Home • News

pages.title: Health Education England » Help support and shape workforce planning within the NHS
pages.content: 27 June 2013 - 15:58 Health Education England (HEE) is calling for evidence to help support and shape workforce planning within the NHS. With over 1.3 million staff performing over 300 different types of jobs across more than a 1000 different employers, the NHS requires a robust workforce planning process to ensure we have staff in the right numbers, with the right skills and the right values and behaviours to deliver high quality care. HEE has published comprehensive workforce planning guidance for the NHS – the first of its kind seen in the NHS. The guidance provides clarity for the system about who needs to do what by when, so that together we can use our different levers and resources to achieve our common goals. It represents a radical departure from what has gone before, and sets out a transparent, evidence based, and risk assessed decision making process setting out the milestones and timelines for the planning process to be operated in 2013/14 to produce 2014/15 workforce investment plans. Our ambition is to secure the future supply of workforce, in a way that both maintains safe staffing levels for patients, whilst supporting the transformation of services necessary to drive quality improvement. In order to help us to fulfil our national role, we need to draw upon the experience and views of key stakeholders. We recognise that many stakeholders have generated important perspectives on the future workforce and we are seeking your support in identifying key issues, perspectives and evidence, which we can use to shape our final plans. All submissions must be evidence based, and address all three components of numbers, skills, values and behaviours, to ensure that our future workforce can deliver high quality care. For more information and to read the guidance click here. If you would like to discuss this further email hee.workforceplanning@nhs.net. Tweet Categories: Home • News

pages.title: Health Education England » Designing HEE’s new Multi Professional Advisory Body (MPAB)
pages.content: 9 July 2013 - 11:36 We have published a report which summarises the key messages from a stakeholder event held on the 19 June 2013 to help design a new Multi Professional Advisory Body (MPAB). At HEE we know that to achieve the best outcomes for patients, we need to develop key relationships with our stakeholders and work in partnership with the wider system to ensure that: • The decisions HEE make are driven by the needs of current and future patients and informed by the advice and expertise of our stakeholders, partners and patients. • HEE receive valuable uni professional advice, along with a multi professional forum to get advice on education, training and workforce planning from across the system To ensure we are able to meet these expectations we conducted a mapping exercise of the existing advisory structures, and sought views from our stakeholders. We found there was a consensus that although the status quo provides a rich source of intelligence and advice, there was a need to revise and simplify the advisory landscape, and design new decision making architecture that would meet our needs. Our new simplified Advisory Arrangements proposed a new Multi Professional Advisory Body (MPAB), as a means by which the board of Health Education England can receive the very best advice from a range of views and perspectives. To help us design our new advisory arrangements, we invited stakeholders to an event on 19 June. The report below summarises the key messages from the event; identifies areas of consensus, key risks and our proposed solutions and outlines next steps for the development of the MPAB. Read the report: Designing HEE’s new Multi Professional Advisory Body (MPAB) If you would like any further information please contact Catherine Dale, Strategy Lead, HEE: Catherine.dale1@nhs.net Tweet Categories: HEE publications • Home • Publications

pages.content: 10 July 2013 - 16:43 In celebration of the National Health Service’s 65th birthday, we look back at how the NHS has been developing people for 65 years with regard to training, education and workforce development. HEE has created an infograph which highlights some of the key mile stones that have taken place over the past 65 years .
